name: OECD Privacy Guidelines
description: Non-binding principles developed by the OECD for personal data protection, covering collection limitation, data quality, purpose specification, use limitation, security safeguards, and more. These guidelines have influenced many national privacy laws.
requirement: Follow non-binding principles on fair data collection, use limitation, and data security.

name: Council of Europe Convention 108+
description: First binding international treaty on data protection, open to global accession. Requires signatory states to implement domestic privacy legislation aligned with its core principles.
jurisdiction: Council of Europe Member States and Global Signatories
requirement: Enact domestic laws ensuring data protection aligned with treaty principles.

name: United Nations Human Rights Framework (UDHR & ICCPR)
description: Recognizes the right to privacy as a fundamental human right under the Universal Declaration of Human Rights (Article 12) and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (Article 17), creating international norms for state conduct.
requirement: Respect and protect the right to privacy as a fundamental human right in domestic legislation and practice.

name: APEC Privacy Framework & Cross-Border Privacy Rules (CBPR)
description: Voluntary privacy framework developed by APEC to promote cross-border data flows and safeguard personal information. Includes the Cross-Border Privacy Rules (CBPR) system for certifying companies’ compliance.
requirement: Align internal privacy policies with APEC principles and seek CBPR certification for cross-border data transfers.

name: California Consumer Privacy Act (CCPA) / California Privacy Rights Act (CPRA)
description: State law granting California residents rights over their personal data, including notice, access, deletion, and opt-out of data sale. Imposes transparency and security obligations on businesses handling Californians' data. The CPRA expanded CCPA provisions and took effect in 2023.
requirement: Provide notice of data collection, allow data access and deletion, and enable opt-out of data sale.

name: Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA)
description: Federal law that sets privacy and security standards for protecting the confidentiality of health information (PHI). HIPAA applies to healthcare providers, insurers, and their vendors, mandating safeguarding of medical records and limiting the use and disclosure of health data.
requirement: Safeguard protected health information (PHI) and limit its use and disclosure.

name: Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act (GLBA)
description: Federal law that mandates financial institutions to protect consumers' personal financial information. Requires privacy notices to customers and safeguarding of sensitive data, including policies on sharing customer information with non-affiliated third parties.
requirement: Provide privacy notices and protect sensitive customer financial data.

name: Children’s Online Privacy Protection Act (COPPA)
description: Federal law that protects the personal data of children under the age of 13 online. Requires parental consent for the collection of data from minors and imposes data minimization and security duties on websites that target children.
requirement: Obtain parental consent for data collection from children under 13 and impose data minimization and security measures.

name: State Privacy Laws
description: Various U.S. states have enacted privacy laws similar to CCPA/CPRA, such as the Virginia CDPA and Colorado Privacy Act, granting consumers rights over their personal data and imposing obligations on data controllers. Businesses must monitor and adapt to this evolving patchwork of state regulations.
requirement: Ensure compliance with state-specific consumer data privacy rights and obligations.

name: General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)
description: EU-wide regulation protecting personal data of individuals. Imposes strict requirements including lawful bases for processing, consent, data subject rights, and breach notification. Non-compliance can lead to fines up to 4% of global turnover. Applies extraterritorially to organizations processing EU residents’ data.
requirement: Obtain lawful bases for processing, provide data subject rights, and notify of data breaches.

name: ePrivacy Directive
description: EU directive on privacy in electronic communications, covering topics like cookies, email marketing, and metadata privacy. Requires user consent for tracking cookies and mandates confidentiality of communications. The directive is being replaced by the ePrivacy Regulation, which is pending as of 2025.
requirement: Obtain user consent for tracking cookies and ensure confidentiality of electronic communications.

name: EU-U.S. Data Privacy Framework
description: A new trans-Atlantic data transfer arrangement established in 2023 that recognizes U.S. privacy safeguards as adequate under the GDPR for EU to U.S. data transfers, replacing the invalidated Privacy Shield. Organizations can self-certify compliance with EU privacy principles for data transfers.
requirement: Self-certify compliance with EU privacy principles for EU to U.S. data transfers.

name: UK GDPR & Data Protection Act 2018
description: Post-Brexit UK’s data protection regime, essentially mirroring the EU GDPR with UK-specific adjustments. Ensures the continuity of GDPR principles such as lawfulness, transparency, and data subject rights within UK law. Enforcement by the Information Commissioner's Office (ICO), with substantial fines for violations.
requirement: Ensure lawfulness and transparency in data processing, uphold data subject rights, and comply with data protection principles.

name: Privacy and Electronic Communications Regulations (PECR)
description: UK regulations analogous to the EU ePrivacy Directive, governing the use of cookies and direct marketing consents. It mandates user consent for tracking cookies and establishes rules for confidentiality in electronic communications.
requirement: Obtain user consent for cookies and ensure confidentiality of communications in direct marketing activities.

name: Personal Information Protection and Electronic Documents Act (PIPEDA)
description: Federal law in Canada regulating private-sector data privacy across provinces (except those with substantially similar laws). It mandates consent for data collection, gives individuals access and correction rights, and limits the amount of data collected.
requirement: Obtain consent for data collection, provide access and correction rights to individuals, and limit data collection.

name: Provincial Privacy Laws
description: Several Canadian provinces have their own private-sector privacy acts, such as Alberta's PIPA, B.C.'s PIPA, and Québec’s Law 25. These laws are largely aligned with PIPEDA and GDPR principles, and apply in their respective provinces instead of PIPEDA.
requirement: Ensure compliance with privacy laws within their respective provinces and adhere to GDPR-like principles.

name: Privacy Act (Canada)
description: Federal law governing the personal data practices of government agencies in Canada, ensuring that citizens have the right to access and correct their personal information held by government bodies.
requirement: Ensure citizens' right to access and correct personal data held by government agencies.

name: Personal Information Protection Law (PIPL)
description: China’s comprehensive data protection law enacted in 2021, similar to GDPR in scope and rights. Requires consent or other lawful bases for processing personal information, mandates security measures, and imposes strict conditions on exporting personal data out of China. Certain sensitive personal information must be stored within China unless approved by authorities.
requirement: Obtain consent or other lawful bases for processing personal data, ensure security measures, and store sensitive data within China unless approved for export.

name: Data Security Law (DSL)
description: Enacted in 2021, the Data Security Law classifies data based on its importance to China’s national security and economy. It imposes data localization requirements and security assessments for the transfer of 'important data' abroad. It also mandates ongoing data risk monitoring.
requirement: Classify data based on importance to national security, conduct security assessments for important data transfers, and implement data risk monitoring.

name: Cybersecurity Law
description: Enacted in 2017, this law introduced personal data protections and mandates that Critical Information Infrastructure (CII) operators store personal and important data within China. It forms the foundation of China's cybersecurity and data localization regime.
requirement: Ensure data storage within China for Critical Information Infrastructure operators and adhere to cybersecurity protection measures.

name: Digital Personal Data Protection Act (DPDP Act)
description: India’s new comprehensive privacy law, passed in 2023, which establishes consent requirements, personal data processing principles, data subject rights (access, correction, erasure), and cross-border transfer rules. Enforcement is handled by a Data Protection Board, with fines for breaches. It replaces the older Personal Data Protection Bill.
requirement: Obtain consent for personal data processing, provide data subject rights (access, correction, erasure), and follow cross-border data transfer rules.

name: Information Technology Act & SPDI Rules
description: India’s legacy regime consisting of the IT Act (2000) and the Sensitive Personal Data or Information (SPDI) Rules (2011), which require organizations to obtain consent for processing sensitive personal data (e.g., financial, health data) and adopt reasonable security practices. These provisions remain in effect until the DPDP Act is fully operational.
requirement: Obtain consent for processing sensitive personal data, ensure reasonable security practices, and continue to comply until the DPDP Act takes full effect.

name: Cert-In Rules
description: Imposed by the Indian Computer Emergency Response Team (CERT-In) in 2022, these rules require certain entities to report data breaches within 6 hours and store logs for specified periods. It significantly impacts data governance in India.
requirement: Report data breaches within 6 hours and store logs for the specified duration according to CERT-In’s rules.

name: Act on Protection of Personal Information (APPI)
description: Japan's main privacy law, last amended in 2020. It applies to businesses handling personal data and requires notice and purpose limitation, safeguards, individual rights (access/correction), and restrictions on cross-border transfers (requiring consent or adequacy). Japan obtained EU adequacy for APPI in 2019.
requirement: Provide notice for data collection, limit purpose of processing, safeguard data, and ensure cross-border transfers meet consent or adequacy requirements.

name: Guidelines under APPI
description: Detailed sectoral guidelines issued by the Personal Information Protection Commission (PPC) and relevant ministries, supplementing the APPI law. These guidelines cover sectors such as credit, healthcare, and telecommunications, providing best practices and legal interpretations.
requirement: Follow sector-specific guidelines for best practices in personal data handling, as provided by PPC and ministries.

name: Personal Information Protection Act (PIPA)
description: South Korea's comprehensive privacy law, enacted in 2011 and amended in 2020, is one of the strictest. It regulates personal data across all sectors, requiring consent for collection/use, data minimization, breach notification, and heavy penalties for violations. Enforced by the Personal Information Protection Commission (PIPC). South Korea gained EU adequacy in 2021 due to strong protections.
requirement: Obtain consent for data collection, minimize data usage, notify about breaches, and comply with strict penalties for violations.

name: Personal Data Protection Act (PDPA)
description: Singapore’s Personal Data Protection Act (PDPA), enacted in 2012 and updated in 2020, governs personal data in the private sector. It requires consent (or deemed consent) for collection and use, notification of purposes, and reasonable security measures. Recent updates introduced mandatory breach notification and expanded consent exceptions. It also has limited data localization for certain sectors.
requirement: Obtain consent for personal data collection, notify about the purpose, ensure security, and notify breaches. Limited data localization for certain sectors.

name: Hong Kong PDPO
description: Hong Kong's Personal Data (Privacy) Ordinance (PDPO) is one of Asia's earliest privacy laws, enacted in 1995. It sets data protection principles and includes a complaint mechanism under the Privacy Commissioner.
requirement: Comply with data protection principles and facilitate complaints under the Privacy Commissioner.

name: Australia Privacy Act
description: Australia's Privacy Act 1988 governs privacy and data protection, aligning with the Australian Privacy Principles (APPs). It is similar to GDPR and PIPEDA. Currently, it is under review for strengthening, especially regarding consent and transparency.
requirement: Comply with Australian Privacy Principles (APPs), focusing on transparency, consent, and data protection.

name: Thailand PDPA
description: Thailand’s Personal Data Protection Act (PDPA), enacted in 2022, is closely modeled on the GDPR, requiring consent for data processing and providing individuals with rights to access, correct, and erase data. It aims to protect personal data in line with international standards.
requirement: Obtain consent for data processing, and provide individuals with rights to access, correct, and erase their data.

name: Act on the Protection of Personal Information (APPI)
description: Japan's main privacy law, enacted in 2003 and significantly amended in 2020. The amendments introduced stricter regulations on data protection and cross-border data transfers. Key provisions came into effect on 12 December 2020, with the remaining provisions implemented on 1 April 2022.
requirement: Obtain consent for data collection, ensure data security, and comply with cross-border data transfer regulations.

name: Personal Information Protection Act (PIPA)
description: South Korea's comprehensive privacy law, enacted in 2011 and amended in 2020, is considered one of the strictest. It regulates personal data across all sectors, requiring consent for collection/use, data minimization, breach notification, and heavy penalties for violations. Enforced by the Personal Information Protection Commission (PIPC). South Korea gained EU adequacy in 2021 due to strong protections.
requirement: Obtain consent for data collection, minimize data usage, notify about breaches, and comply with strict penalties for violations.

name: Personal Data Protection Act (PDPA)
description: Singapore's Personal Data Protection Act (PDPA), enacted in 2012 and amended in 2020, governs personal data in the private sector. It requires consent (or deemed consent) for collection and use, notification of purposes, and reasonable security measures. Recent updates introduced mandatory breach notification and expanded consent exceptions. Limited data localization for certain sectors.
requirement: Obtain consent for personal data collection, notify about the purpose, ensure security, and notify breaches. Limited data localization for certain sectors.

name: Personal Data (Privacy) Ordinance (PDPO)
description: Hong Kong's Personal Data (Privacy) Ordinance (PDPO), enacted in 1995 and effective from December 1996, is one of Asia's earliest privacy laws. It sets data protection principles and includes a complaint mechanism under the Privacy Commissioner. Major amendments in 2012 and 2021 addressed direct marketing and doxxing acts, respectively.
requirement: Comply with data protection principles, facilitate complaints under the Privacy Commissioner, and adhere to regulations against doxxing.

name: Privacy Act 1988
description: Australia's Privacy Act 1988 governs privacy and data protection, aligning with the Australian Privacy Principles (APPs). It is similar to GDPR and PIPEDA. The Act has undergone several amendments, with the latest version effective from 1 February 2025.
requirement: Comply with Australian Privacy Principles (APPs), focusing on transparency, consent, and data protection.

name: Personal Data Protection Act (PDPA)
description: Thailand’s Personal Data Protection Act (PDPA), enacted in 2019 and effective from 1 June 2022, is closely modeled on the GDPR, requiring consent for data processing and providing individuals with rights to access, correct, and erase data. It aims to protect personal data in line with international standards.
requirement: Obtain consent for data processing, and provide individuals with rights to access, correct, and erase their data.

Recent updates introduced mandatory breach notification and expanded consent exceptions. Limited data localization for certain sectors.
requirement: Obtain consent for personal data collection, notify about the purpose, ensure security, and notify breaches. Limited data localization for certain sectors.

description: Hong Kong's Personal Data (Privacy) Ordinance (PDPO), enacted in 1995 and effective from December 1996, is one of Asia's earliest privacy laws. It sets data protection principles and includes a complaint mechanism under the Privacy Commissioner. Major amendments in 2012 and 2021 addressed direct marketing and doxxing acts, respectively.
requirement: Comply with data protection principles, facilitate complaints under the Privacy Commissioner, and adhere to regulations against doxxing.

name: Privacy Act 1988
description: Australia's Privacy Act 1988 governs privacy and data protection, aligning with the Australian Privacy Principles (APPs). It is similar to GDPR and PIPEDA. The Act has undergone several amendments, with the latest version effective from 1 February 2025.
requirement: Comply with Australian Privacy Principles (APPs), focusing on transparency, consent, and data protection.

name: Personal Data Protection Act (PDPA)
description: Thailand’s Personal Data Protection Act (PDPA), enacted in 2019 and effective from 1 June 2022, is closely modeled on the GDPR, requiring consent for data processing and providing individuals with rights to access, correct, and erase data. It aims to protect personal data in line with international standards.
requirement: Obtain consent for data processing, and provide individuals with rights to access, correct, and erase their data.

name: Bank Secrecy Act (BSA)
description: The foundational U.S. anti-money laundering law requiring financial institutions to maintain AML programs, keep records of financial transactions, and report large or suspicious activity to FinCEN.
requirement: File Currency Transaction Reports (CTRs ≥ $10,000), Suspicious Activity Reports (SARs), maintain AML compliance programs, and retain relevant transaction records.

name: USA PATRIOT Act
description: Passed after 9/11 to enhance AML and counter-terrorist financing controls. Strengthened the BSA with customer identification rules (CIP), watchlist screening, and prohibitions on foreign shell banks.
requirement: Implement customer identification programs (CIP), conduct KYC screening, prohibit accounts with shell banks, and share information with government authorities.

name: Anti-Money Laundering Act of 2020 (AMLA)
description: Part of the 2021 NDAA, this act modernized U.S. AML laws. It introduced beneficial ownership reporting via the Corporate Transparency Act, expanded FinCEN powers, and created stronger penalties and whistleblower incentives.
requirement: Report beneficial ownership to FinCEN; comply with updated enforcement and whistleblower rules; subject to expanded foreign subpoena powers.

name: FinCEN Regulations (e.g., CDD Rule)
description: Rules issued under the BSA by FinCEN. Includes the 2016 Customer Due Diligence Rule requiring financial institutions to identify beneficial owners and maintain risk-based AML controls.
requirement: Identify and verify beneficial owners of legal entity customers, monitor ongoing customer relationships, and update risk profiles accordingly.

name: OFAC Sanctions Regulations
description: Regulations enforced by the Office of Foreign Assets Control requiring financial institutions to screen customers and transactions against U.S. sanctions lists (e.g., SDN list).
requirement: Screen customers and transactions against OFAC sanctions lists, block or reject prohibited transactions, and report matches.

name: Industry-Specific AML Requirements
description: AML program mandates across regulated sectors like banks, MSBs, casinos, insurance firms, broker-dealers, and virtual asset service providers. Varies by industry but follows BSA principles.
requirement: Develop and implement risk-based AML programs tailored to specific industries; comply with FinCEN guidance and geographic targeting orders where applicable.

name: 4th Anti-Money Laundering Directive (4AMLD)
description: Established a risk-based AML approach across the EU. Extended AML obligations to gambling services and required member states to create beneficial ownership registries.
requirement: Implement risk-based AML measures, include gambling services in scope, establish UBO registries.

name: 5th Anti-Money Laundering Directive (5AMLD)
description: Expanded AML scope to virtual asset service providers and prepaid cards, required public access to UBO registries, and imposed enhanced due diligence for high-risk third countries.
requirement: Register crypto providers, allow public access to UBO data, conduct enhanced due diligence on high-risk countries.

name: 6th Anti-Money Laundering Directive (6AMLD)
description: Introduced a common definition of 22 predicate offenses (e.g., cybercrime, tax crimes), extended criminal liability to legal entities, and imposed minimum penalties for money laundering.
requirement: Criminalize money laundering, include companies in liability scope, impose minimum 4-year prison terms.

name: EU AML Regulation (Proposed)
description: Proposed regulation to unify AML rules across the EU, directly applicable in all member states. Includes detailed customer due diligence, risk management, and supervision standards.
requirement: Directly applicable rules on AML/CFT, harmonized CDD, transaction monitoring, and recordkeeping obligations.

name: Anti-Money Laundering Authority (AMLA)
description: New EU-level AML supervisory body to directly oversee high-risk financial institutions and coordinate with national supervisors.
requirement: Direct supervision of selected entities, coordination across EU member states, enforcement of AML Regulation.

name: Funds Transfer Regulation (EU) 2015/847
description: Implements FATF’s Travel Rule in the EU. Requires payment service providers to include originator and beneficiary information in wire transfers to prevent anonymity in financial flows.
requirement: Include originator/beneficiary info in fund transfers; verify data accuracy and completeness.

name: National AML Laws (e.g., Germany, France)
description: Each EU member state transposes AMLDs into its own legal system. Examples include Germany's Geldwäschegesetz and France's Code Monétaire et Financier.
requirement: National laws reflect EU directives, with enforcement by national FIUs and regulators in coordination with EU framework.

name: 4th Anti-Money Laundering Directive (4AMLD)
description: Established a risk-based AML approach across the EU. Extended AML obligations to gambling services and required member states to create beneficial ownership registries.
requirement: Implement risk-based AML measures, include gambling services in scope, establish UBO registries.

name: 5th Anti-Money Laundering Directive (5AMLD)
description: Expanded AML scope to virtual asset service providers and prepaid cards, required public access to UBO registries, and imposed enhanced due diligence for high-risk third countries.
requirement: Register crypto providers, allow public access to UBO data, conduct enhanced due diligence on high-risk countries.

name: 6th Anti-Money Laundering Directive (6AMLD)
description: Introduced a common definition of 22 predicate offenses (e.g., cybercrime, tax crimes), extended criminal liability to legal entities, and imposed minimum penalties for money laundering.
requirement: Criminalize money laundering, include companies in liability scope, impose minimum 4-year prison terms.

name: EU AML Regulation (Proposed)
description: Proposed regulation to unify AML rules across the EU, directly applicable in all member states. Includes detailed customer due diligence, risk management, and supervision standards.
requirement: Directly applicable rules on AML/CFT, harmonized CDD, transaction monitoring, and recordkeeping obligations.

name: Anti-Money Laundering Authority (AMLA)
description: New EU-level AML supervisory body to directly oversee high-risk financial institutions and coordinate with national supervisors.
requirement: Direct supervision of selected entities, coordination across EU member states, enforcement of AML Regulation.

name: Funds Transfer Regulation (EU) 2015/847
description: Implements FATF’s Travel Rule in the EU. Requires payment service providers to include originator and beneficiary information in wire transfers to prevent anonymity in financial flows.
requirement: Include originator/beneficiary info in fund transfers; verify data accuracy and completeness.

name: National AML Laws (e.g., Germany, France)
description: Each EU member state transposes AMLDs into its own legal system. Examples include Germany's Geldwäschegesetz and France's Code Monétaire et Financier.
requirement: National laws reflect EU directives, with enforcement by national FIUs and regulators in coordination with EU framework.

name: Proceeds of Crime (Money Laundering) and Terrorist Financing Act (PCMLTFA)
description: Canada's primary AML/CFT legislation. Applies to financial institutions, casinos, MSBs, real estate brokers, and others. Requires client identification, recordkeeping, and reporting of suspicious and large transactions.
requirement: Imposes obligations on reporting entities to conduct KYC, report large cash/electronic fund transfers, and file suspicious activity reports.

name: FINTRAC Regulations
description: Regulations under the PCMLTFA enforced by FINTRAC. Detail KYC methods, thresholds for reporting, timing of suspicious transaction reports, and ongoing monitoring requirements.
requirement: Reporting entities must verify identities, perform ongoing due diligence, and submit reports to FINTRAC within specified timelines.

name: Criminal Code of Canada – Money Laundering and Terrorist Financing Offenses
description: Makes money laundering and terrorist financing criminal offenses. Enables prosecution of individuals and entities involved in illicit financial activities.
requirement: Criminalizes the laundering of proceeds of crime and financing of terrorism, complements regulatory obligations under PCMLTFA.

name: Provincial AML/CFT Measures
description: Initiatives by provinces like British Columbia (beneficial ownership registry for real estate) and Ontario (land ownership transparency) to prevent property-based money laundering.
requirement: Mandates disclosure of beneficial ownership and targets money laundering through property markets.

name: Proceeds of Crime (Money Laundering) and Terrorist Financing Act (PCMLTFA)
description: Canada's primary AML/CFT legislation. Applies to financial institutions, casinos, MSBs, real estate brokers, and others. Requires client identification, recordkeeping, and reporting of suspicious and large transactions.
requirement: Imposes obligations on reporting entities to conduct KYC, report large cash/electronic fund transfers, and file suspicious activity reports.

name: FINTRAC Regulations
description: Regulations under the PCMLTFA enforced by FINTRAC. Detail KYC methods, thresholds for reporting, timing of suspicious transaction reports, and ongoing monitoring requirements.
requirement: Reporting entities must verify identities, perform ongoing due diligence, and submit reports to FINTRAC within specified timelines.

name: Criminal Code of Canada – Money Laundering and Terrorist Financing Offenses
description: Makes money laundering and terrorist financing criminal offenses. Enables prosecution of individuals and entities involved in illicit financial activities.
requirement: Criminalizes the laundering of proceeds of crime and financing of terrorism, complements regulatory obligations under PCMLTFA.

name: Provincial AML/CFT Measures
description: Initiatives by provinces like British Columbia (beneficial ownership registry for real estate) and Ontario (land ownership transparency) to prevent property-based money laundering.
requirement: Mandates disclosure of beneficial ownership and targets money laundering through property markets.

name: United Nations Convention against Corruption (UNCAC)
description: The only universal anti-corruption treaty, requiring criminalization of domestic and foreign bribery, money laundering, and implementation of preventive measures, asset recovery, and international cooperation.
requirement: Criminalize bribery and corruption, enforce preventive frameworks, promote asset recovery and mutual legal assistance.

name: OECD Convention on Combating Bribery of Foreign Public Officials
description: Legally binding treaty requiring signatories to criminalize bribery of foreign public officials and ensure companies maintain accurate books and records to prevent corruption in international business.
requirement: Criminalize foreign bribery, enforce recordkeeping, and implement related corporate governance mechanisms.

name: OECD Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises
description: Voluntary principles encouraging multinational companies to avoid bribery and corruption, including implementation of internal compliance programs and transparent business practices.
requirement: Implement due diligence and compliance systems; avoid corrupt practices.

name: Inter-American Convention Against Corruption
description: OAS treaty requiring member states to adopt laws and practices to prevent and criminalize corruption, including bribery of domestic and foreign officials.
requirement: Adopt domestic anti-bribery laws, establish oversight mechanisms, and promote regional cooperation.

name: African Union Convention on Preventing and Combating Corruption
description: African Union agreement committing signatories to criminalize corruption and implement national anti-bribery measures including transparency and integrity in public life.
requirement: Enact anti-bribery laws, promote good governance, and enforce corruption prevention strategies.

name: Transparency International & ISO 37001 Anti-Bribery Management Systems
description: Guidelines and certification standards providing frameworks for companies to establish anti-bribery programs, including risk assessment, controls, training, due diligence, and monitoring.
requirement: Implement internal controls, risk assessments, training, and continuous improvement to prevent bribery.

name: Bank Secrecy Act (BSA)
description: The foundational U.S. AML law requiring financial institutions to establish AML programs, maintain transaction records, and report certain transactions to authorities, including Currency Transaction Reports (CTRs) and Suspicious Activity Reports (SARs).
requirement: Implement AML programs, file CTRs for cash transactions ≥ $10,000, and file SARs for suspicious activities.

name: USA PATRIOT Act
description: U.S. law expanding AML measures post-9/11. Enhances customer due diligence, mandates identity verification (CIP), and prohibits relationships with foreign shell banks.
requirement: Enhanced CDD/KYC, identity verification, screening against watchlists, prohibition on shell bank accounts.

name: Anti-Money Laundering Act of 2020 (AMLA)
description: Major update to U.S. AML framework, including beneficial ownership reporting (Corporate Transparency Act), stronger penalties, and enhanced subpoena powers.
requirement: File beneficial ownership info with FinCEN, comply with increased penalties, respond to expanded subpoena authority.

name: FinCEN and OFAC Regulations
description: Rules issued under the BSA and by OFAC. FinCEN regulations define CDD requirements and beneficial ownership, while OFAC mandates sanctions screening.
requirement: Comply with CDD Rule, identify beneficial owners, perform OFAC screening.

name: Industry-Specific AML Regulations
description: AML obligations tailored to specific sectors such as banks, MSBs, casinos, broker-dealers, insurance firms, and crypto exchanges, enforced by FinCEN and others.
requirement: Implement AML programs per sector guidance, report CTRs/SARs, and comply with geographic targeting orders.

requirement: File beneficial ownership info with FinCEN, comply with increased penalties, respond to expanded subpoena authority.

name: Industry-Specific AML Regulations
description: AML obligations tailored to specific sectors such as banks, MSBs, casinos, broker-dealers, insurance firms, and crypto exchanges, enforced by FinCEN and others.
requirement: Implement AML programs per sector guidance, report CTRs/SARs, and comply with geographic targeting orders.

name: Proceeds of Crime Act 2002 (POCA)
description: UK legislation criminalizing money laundering and setting out key offenses such as concealment, acquisition, and failure to report. Establishes asset confiscation and Suspicious Activity Reporting (SAR) regime.
requirement: Report suspicious activities, prevent and detect money laundering, enable asset recovery.

name: Money Laundering, Terrorist Financing and Transfer of Funds (Information) Regulations 2017
description: UK regulation implementing EU AMLDs, requiring customer due diligence, record-keeping, and suspicious activity reporting. Amended to include cryptoasset businesses and UBO registers.
requirement: CDD/KYC, UBO registry, reporting suspicious transactions and maintaining records.

name: Terrorism Act 2000
description: UK law criminalizing terrorist financing and requiring reporting of knowledge or suspicion. Forms the basis of TF Suspicious Activity Reporting alongside POCA.
requirement: Report terrorist financing suspicions, prohibit funding of terrorism.

name: UK AML Supervisory Regime
description: Framework involving multiple UK supervisory authorities (e.g., FCA, HMRC, Gambling Commission) overseeing AML compliance. Includes JMLIT for public-private sector intelligence sharing.
requirement: Ensure AML compliance through sectoral oversight and information sharing.

name: Proceeds of Crime (Money Laundering) and Terrorist Financing Act (PCMLTFA)
description: Canada’s primary AML/CFT law imposing obligations on reporting entities (e.g., banks, casinos, real estate) to identify clients, maintain records, report certain transactions and suspicious activities.
requirement: Identify clients, report large transactions, monitor for suspicious activities, ensure compliance with AML regulations.

name: FINTRAC Regulations
description: Detailed regulations under the PCMLTFA enforced by FINTRAC, Canada's Financial Intelligence Unit (FIU). It covers KYC, ongoing monitoring, and suspicious transaction reporting (STR) requirements.
requirement: KYC identity verification, ongoing monitoring, STR filing within 30 days of detection.

name: Criminal Code
description: Canada’s Criminal Code criminalizes money laundering and terrorist financing. It also enforces targeted financial sanctions via the UN Act and the Special Economic Measures Act.
requirement: Prohibit money laundering and terrorist financing activities, comply with financial sanctions regulations.

name: Provincial Initiatives
description: Various provinces in Canada have enacted their own anti-money laundering measures, particularly in the real estate and legal sectors, such as B.C.'s beneficial ownership registry for properties.
requirement: Implement provincial-specific AML measures such as beneficial ownership registries and transparency in property ownership.

name: China Criminal Law - Money Laundering
description: Criminalizes money laundering activities in China. The People’s Bank of China issues AML regulations for financial institutions, and banks must conduct customer ID verification and report large or suspicious transactions to the China AML Monitoring and Analysis Center.
requirement: Financial institutions must verify customer identity and report large or suspicious transactions.

name: Hong Kong Anti-Money Laundering and Counter-Terrorist Financing Ordinance (AMLO)
description: Mandates customer due diligence and record-keeping for banks, securities firms, casinos, and other regulated entities. It also includes cross-boundary movement of physical currency reporting requirements.
requirement: Regulated entities must maintain customer records, conduct due diligence, and comply with currency movement reporting.

name: Singapore Corruption, Drug Trafficking and Other Serious Crimes (Confiscation of Benefits) Act (CDSA)
description: Criminalizes money laundering and imposes AML/CFT measures including customer due diligence, ongoing monitoring, and suspicious transaction reporting (STR) through MAS Notice 626.
requirement: Banks and other entities must implement AML measures such as KYC, ongoing monitoring, and STR filing.

name: Japan Act on Prevention of Transfer of Criminal Proceeds
description: Requires financial institutions to verify customer identity and report suspicious transactions to Japan’s FIU. This law also applies to virtual currency exchanges.
requirement: Financial institutions must verify customer identity and report suspicious transactions.

name: India Prevention of Money Laundering Act (PMLA) 2002
description: Core AML law criminalizing money laundering activities and imposing reporting obligations on financial institutions. The law was updated in 2023 to include crypto exchanges as reporting entities.
requirement: Banks and intermediaries must submit Currency Transaction Reports (CTRs) and Suspicious Transaction Reports (STRs).

name: Australia Anti-Money Laundering and Counter-Terrorism Financing Act 2006
description: Requires reporting entities to register with AUSTRAC, implement customer due diligence (KYC), and report suspicious matters and large cash transactions.
requirement: Register with AUSTRAC, conduct KYC, and report large transactions (≥ AUD 10,000) and suspicious matters.

name: Other APAC Anti-Money Laundering Laws
description: Most Asia-Pacific economies (e.g., Malaysia, Indonesia, South Korea, Thailand) have AML laws in line with FATF standards, including customer due diligence and suspicious transaction reporting.
requirement: Implement FATF-aligned AML measures including customer due diligence, monitoring, and STR reporting.

name: United Nations Convention against Corruption (UNCAC)
description: A global treaty ratified by approximately 189 countries, requiring parties to criminalize bribery (both domestic and foreign), embezzlement, and money laundering. It mandates the implementation of preventive measures like codes of conduct, transparent public procurement, and independent anti-corruption bodies, alongside asset recovery and international cooperation.
requirement: Criminalize bribery (domestic and foreign), implement preventive measures, and facilitate international cooperation on anti-corruption.

name: OECD Convention on Combating Bribery (OECD Anti-Bribery Convention)
description: A 1997 treaty that requires signatory countries (44 nations) to criminalize bribery of foreign public officials and mandates the maintenance of accurate books and records to prevent off-book bribes. This convention has led to laws such as the UK Bribery Act and amendments to the U.S. FCPA.
requirement: Criminalize bribery of foreign public officials, maintain accurate books and records to prevent off-book bribes.

name: OECD Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises
description: Voluntary guidelines for multinational enterprises that include provisions urging companies not to engage in bribery and to establish internal compliance systems. Though not legally binding, these guidelines are widely recognized as a corporate social responsibility (CSR) standard.
requirement: Develop internal compliance systems and refrain from bribery, aligned with CSR principles.

name: Inter-American Convention Against Corruption
description: A 1996 treaty for OAS countries committing them to enact anti-bribery laws and measures, complementing the UNCAC by regionally promoting transparency and anti-corruption efforts.
requirement: Enact anti-bribery laws, promote good governance, and combat corruption regionally.

name: African Union Convention on Preventing and Combating Corruption
description: A 2003 African Union treaty that commits signatories to criminalize bribery and implement anti-corruption measures regionally. It aims to promote transparency and good governance in Africa.
requirement: Criminalize bribery, enforce anti-corruption measures, and promote good governance regionally.

name: Transparency International & ISO 37001
description: TI’s guidance and ISO 37001 (Anti-Bribery Management Systems, 2016) provide frameworks for organizations to implement anti-bribery compliance programs, including policies, risk assessments, training, controls, and due diligence.
requirement: Implement comprehensive anti-bribery compliance programs including risk assessments, training, and due diligence.

name: Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (FCPA)
description: A U.S. law that prohibits the bribery of foreign government officials to obtain or retain business. It applies to U.S. companies, citizens, and foreign companies listed in the U.S. It has two parts: anti-bribery provisions and accounting provisions, requiring accurate books and internal controls to prevent bribery.
requirement: Prohibit bribery of foreign government officials and require companies to maintain accurate books and internal controls.

name: Travel Act
description: A U.S. law that enables prosecutors to charge bribery involving interstate commerce (including commercial bribery) as a federal crime. Often used in conjunction with state law violations for private-sector or domestic bribery.
requirement: Allow federal prosecution of bribery involving interstate commerce and commercial bribery.

name: Anti-Kickback Statutes
description: Laws, such as the Medicare/Medicaid Anti-Kickback Statute, criminalizing the payment of kickbacks to induce referrals or purchases in federal healthcare programs.
requirement: Criminalize the payment of kickbacks to induce referrals or purchases in federal healthcare programs.

name: State Commercial Bribery Laws
description: Laws in most U.S. states that outlaw bribery of private entities' agents (commercial bribery) and bribery of state or local public officials. These laws complement federal laws like the FCPA but focus on domestic operations.
requirement: Outlaw bribery of private entities’ agents and state/local public officials.

name: UK Bribery Act 2010
description: A comprehensive anti-corruption law that criminalizes bribing another person, being bribed, bribing a foreign public official, and the failure of commercial organizations to prevent bribery. Companies can be held liable for the actions of employees or agents unless they have adequate procedures to prevent bribery. The law applies to any company or person with a close connection to the UK.
requirement: Criminalize bribery and failure to prevent bribery by companies. Requires companies to have adequate anti-bribery procedures.

name: Proceeds of Crime Act 2002 & Money Laundering Regulations
description: These laws are often triggered by bribery, as bribery proceeds may be concealed, leading to violations of money laundering laws. Companies are obligated to report knowledge or suspicion of bribery proceeds, or they risk committing a money laundering offense under the Proceeds of Crime Act (POCA).
requirement: Report knowledge or suspicion of bribery proceeds to avoid violating money laundering laws.

name: UK Corporate Governance Code & Listing Rules
description: Although not legally binding, these guidelines set expectations for companies listed on the London Stock Exchange to implement robust internal controls, including anti-bribery measures. They also require companies to report on principal risks, including the risk of corruption.
requirement: Have robust internal controls, including anti-bribery measures, and report on corruption risks.

name: Sapin II Law 2016
description: France's anti-corruption law that mandates large companies to implement anti-corruption compliance programs and established the Agence Française Anticorruption to oversee enforcement. The law strengthens France’s commitment to the OECD and UNCAC anti-corruption standards.
requirement: Large companies must implement anti-corruption compliance programs.

name: Germany's Criminal Code & Corporate Liability Act
description: Germany criminalizes bribery through sections of its Criminal Code, and the Corporate Liability Act under development will hold companies accountable for bribery and corruption. The new act aims to improve corporate responsibility for anti-bribery practices and strengthen enforcement.
requirement: Companies must ensure anti-bribery measures are in place or face corporate liability for violations.

name: Legislative Decree 231 (Italy)
description: Italy's Legislative Decree 231 mandates organizations to adopt models to prevent crimes like corruption. Companies that fail to implement these organizational models can be held liable for bribery and other offenses.
requirement: Companies must adopt organizational models to prevent corruption and other crimes.

name: EU Anti-Corruption Directives
description: The European Union has issued directives on public procurement integrity and anti-corruption mechanisms, which include mandates for transparency and anti-corruption measures in public procurement processes. Additionally, the EU has developed a whistleblower protection directive in 2019 to protect those who report bribery and corruption.
requirement: Ensure integrity in public procurement and protect whistleblowers reporting bribery.

name: Russia's Anti-Bribery Laws
description: Russia enhanced its anti-bribery laws, criminalizing the bribery of foreign public officials and commercial bribery. The laws also introduced corporate liability for failure to prevent bribery, with fines imposed on companies involved in bribery activities.
requirement: Companies must prevent bribery and are liable for bribery violations.

name: Corruption of Foreign Public Officials Act (CFPOA)
description: Canada's equivalent of the U.S. Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (FCPA). The CFPOA criminalizes bribing foreign public officials and falsifying books to conceal such bribery. It applies to Canadian individuals and companies, regardless of location. Enforcement of the CFPOA has increased, with notable prosecutions for overseas bribery.
requirement: Criminalize bribery of foreign public officials and prevent falsifying books to conceal bribery.

name: Criminal Code (Domestic Bribery)
description: Canada's Criminal Code criminalizes bribery of Canadian public officials, municipal officials, fraud on the government, and secret commissions (commercial bribery). The penalties for public sector bribery can include imprisonment of up to 14 years.
requirement: Criminalize bribery of public officials, commercial bribery, and fraud on the government.

name: Provincial Integrity Laws & Codes of Conduct
description: Various provinces in Canada have adopted public sector integrity laws and codes of conduct that address issues of bribery and corruption in provincial government operations. These laws aim to promote transparency and accountability. Additionally, companies convicted of corruption offenses can be debarred from federal contracts under Canada's Integrity Regime.
requirement: Adopt integrity laws and codes of conduct for public sector operations, and enforce debarment for companies convicted of corruption.

name: Criminal Law (China)
description: China's Criminal Law criminalizes both the giving and receiving of bribes, including bribes to foreign officials, following the 2011 amendment. The National Supervisory Commission oversees public sector corruption. The Unfair Competition Law addresses commercial bribery. China cooperates on anti-corruption measures via the UNCAC, although it is not part of the OECD Anti-Bribery Convention.
requirement: Criminalize giving and receiving bribes, including foreign bribery, and address commercial bribery.

name: Prevention of Corruption Act 1988 (India)
description: The Prevention of Corruption Act criminalizes bribery involving public servants and was amended in 2018 to also criminalize giving a bribe. The amendment also introduced corporate liability, holding companies responsible if any associated person pays a bribe unless the company had adequate procedures to prevent it. India does not have a specific foreign bribery law but covers bribery of Indian public officials.
requirement: Criminalize bribery of public servants and impose corporate liability for bribery.

name: Unfair Competition Prevention Act (Japan)
description: Japan’s Criminal Code covers domestic official bribery, while the Unfair Competition Prevention Act criminalizes bribery of foreign public officials, in line with Japan's implementation of the OECD Anti-Bribery Convention. Enforcement has been limited but is improving, with increasing focus on foreign bribery.
requirement: Criminalize domestic and foreign bribery and enforce compliance with OECD standards.

name: Prevention of Corruption Act (PCA) (Singapore)
description: Singapore's Prevention of Corruption Act is a robust anti-corruption law covering both public and private sector bribery. It includes a presumption of guilt for public servants with unexplained wealth. The Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau (CPIB) enforces both domestic and foreign bribery cases.
requirement: Criminalize public and private sector bribery, with presumption of guilt for public servants with unexplained wealth.

name: Criminal Code Division 70 (Australia)
description: Australia's Criminal Code Division 70 prohibits bribery of foreign officials and domestic public bribery. The country is introducing a new offense in 2024 for failure to prevent foreign bribery by corporations, as well as a deferred prosecution agreement regime for companies.
requirement: Prohibit foreign bribery and domestic public bribery; introduce corporate liability for failure to prevent bribery.

name: UNCAC-Aligned Laws (Other APAC)
description: Many Asia-Pacific countries, such as Malaysia, Indonesia, and South Korea, have laws aligned with the UNCAC, criminalizing bribery and establishing anti-corruption measures. For instance, Malaysia’s MACC Act, Indonesia’s Anti-Corruption Law, and South Korea’s Improper Solicitation and Graft Act, which even caps the value of gifts to public officials.
requirement: Criminalize bribery and corruption, with specific regulations on gifts and solicitations.

name: Criminal Law (China)
description: China's Criminal Law criminalizes both the giving and receiving of bribes, including bribes to foreign officials, following the 2011 amendment. The National Supervisory Commission oversees public sector corruption. The Unfair Competition Law addresses commercial bribery. China cooperates on anti-corruption measures via the UNCAC, although it is not part of the OECD Anti-Bribery Convention.
requirement: Criminalize giving and receiving bribes, including foreign bribery, and address commercial bribery.

name: Prevention of Corruption Act 1988 (India)
description: The Prevention of Corruption Act criminalizes bribery involving public servants and was amended in 2018 to also criminalize giving a bribe. The amendment also introduced corporate liability, holding companies responsible if any associated person pays a bribe unless the company had adequate procedures to prevent it. India does not have a specific foreign bribery law but covers bribery of Indian public officials.
requirement: Criminalize bribery of public servants and impose corporate liability for bribery.

name: Unfair Competition Prevention Act (Japan)
description: Japan’s Criminal Code covers domestic official bribery, while the Unfair Competition Prevention Act criminalizes bribery of foreign public officials, in line with Japan's implementation of the OECD Anti-Bribery Convention. Enforcement has been limited but is improving, with increasing focus on foreign bribery.
requirement: Criminalize domestic and foreign bribery and enforce compliance with OECD standards.

name: Prevention of Corruption Act (PCA) (Singapore)
description: Singapore's Prevention of Corruption Act is a robust anti-corruption law covering both public and private sector bribery. It includes a presumption of guilt for public servants with unexplained wealth. The Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau (CPIB) enforces both domestic and foreign bribery cases.
requirement: Criminalize public and private sector bribery, with presumption of guilt for public servants with unexplained wealth.

name: Criminal Code Division 70 (Australia)
description: Australia's Criminal Code Division 70 prohibits bribery of foreign officials and domestic public bribery. The country is introducing a new offense in 2024 for failure to prevent foreign bribery by corporations, as well as a deferred prosecution agreement regime for companies.
requirement: Prohibit foreign bribery and domestic public bribery; introduce corporate liability for failure to prevent bribery.

name: UNCAC-Aligned Laws (Other APAC)
description: Many Asia-Pacific countries, such as Malaysia, Indonesia, and South Korea, have laws aligned with the UNCAC, criminalizing bribery and establishing anti-corruption measures. For instance, Malaysia’s MACC Act, Indonesia’s Anti-Corruption Law, and South Korea’s Improper Solicitation and Graft Act, which even caps the value of gifts to public officials.
requirement: Criminalize bribery and corruption, with specific regulations on gifts and solicitations.

name: Clean Company Act (Brazil) – Law 12,846/2013
description: The Clean Company Act imposes civil and administrative liability on companies for domestic or foreign bribery. Companies can be fined up to 20% of their gross revenue, and compliance programs are incentivized through leniency provisions. It complements Brazil's Penal Code, which criminalizes bribery of local officials. Brazil has been an OECD member since 2000 and has actively pursued bribery cases through Operation Car Wash.
requirement: Criminalize bribery and corporate liability for bribery offenses, incentivize compliance programs.

name: General Law of Administrative Responsibilities (Mexico) – 2016
description: The General Law of Administrative Responsibilities, part of Mexico’s National Anti-Corruption System, imposes corporate liability for bribery (both domestic and foreign) and other corrupt practices. Individual offenders face criminal penalties under the Penal Code. The law aims to increase transparency and accountability in both the public and private sectors.
requirement: Corporate liability for bribery and corruption; criminal penalties for individuals.

name: Corporate Criminal Liability Law (Argentina) – 2018
description: Argentina’s Corporate Criminal Liability Law introduces corporate liability for corruption offenses, including bribing both domestic and foreign officials. The law provides mitigation credit for companies that have compliance programs in place to prevent corruption. This law complements Argentina’s commitment to international anti-corruption frameworks.
requirement: Corporate liability for bribery; mitigation for compliance programs.

name: Anti-Bribery Laws (Chile) – Law 21.121
description: Chile updated its anti-bribery laws with Law 21.121 in 2018, introducing corporate liability for foreign bribery. This law aligns with Chile’s commitments under the OECD Anti-Bribery Convention and extends corporate liability for corrupt acts to include foreign bribery.
requirement: Corporate liability for foreign bribery.

name: Anti-Bribery Laws (Peru) – Legislative Decree 1352
description: Peru’s Legislative Decree 1352, enacted in 2016, criminalizes foreign bribery and establishes corporate liability for such offenses, in line with Peru's OECD commitments. This law aims to enhance corporate governance and transparency in business dealings both domestically and internationally.
requirement: Corporate liability for foreign bribery.

name: Whistleblower Protection Laws (Latin America)
description: Several Latin American countries, including Brazil, Argentina, and Mexico, have introduced whistleblower protection laws to encourage reporting of corruption and bribery. These laws complement anti-corruption efforts and provide legal safeguards to whistleblowers who report wrongdoing in the public and private sectors.
requirement: Protect whistleblowers who report bribery and corruption.

This law aims to enhance corporate governance and transparency in business dealings both domestically and internationally.
requirement: Corporate liability for foreign bribery.

description: Several Latin American countries, including Brazil, Argentina, and Mexico, have introduced whistleblower protection laws to encourage reporting of corruption and bribery. These laws complement anti-corruption efforts and provide legal safeguards to whistleblowers who report wrongdoing in the public and private sectors.
requirement: Protect whistleblowers who report bribery and corruption.

name: People with Significant Control (PSC) Register
description: Since 2016, UK companies and limited liability partnerships (LLPs) are required to report individuals who own or control more than 25% of shares or voting rights, or otherwise exercise significant control over the company. This information is made publicly available via Companies House. The UK was a pioneer in establishing a public beneficial ownership register. Upcoming reforms through the Economic Crime and Corporate Transparency Bill will strengthen the verification of identities on the PSC register.
requirement: Companies must report individuals with significant control (>25%) to Companies House, with public access to this data.

name: Register of Overseas Entities (ROE)
description: Introduced in 2022, the Register of Overseas Entities requires foreign companies that own real estate in the UK to disclose their beneficial owners to Companies House. This initiative aims to curb the use of UK property for laundering dirty money. As of 2023, compliance has been an issue, with many entities failing to report by the deadline. Enforcement actions are underway to ensure proper reporting.
requirement: Overseas entities owning UK property must disclose their beneficial owners to Companies House.

name: Trust Registration Service (TRS)
description: UK trusts, as well as some foreign trusts with UK assets, are required to register their beneficial owners (settlors, trustees, and beneficiaries) with the HMRC Trust Register. While this register is not public, it is accessible to law enforcement and individuals with a legitimate interest. The TRS plays a key role in increasing transparency in the trust sector and preventing misuse for illicit purposes.
requirement: Trusts must register their beneficial owners with HMRC. The information is accessible to law enforcement and those with a legitimate interest.

name: Significant Shareholder Notifications
description: The UK Listing Rules require companies listed on the stock exchange to notify the market whenever a shareholder crosses certain thresholds (e.g., 3%). This requirement is not specifically an anti-money laundering measure but enhances transparency in ownership, ensuring that major changes in corporate control are disclosed. It complements broader corporate transparency and shareholder reporting regulations.
requirement: Listed companies must notify the market of shareholders crossing certain ownership thresholds (3%).

name: People with Significant Control (PSC) Register
description: Since 2016, UK companies and limited liability partnerships (LLPs) are required to report individuals who own or control more than 25% of shares or voting rights, or otherwise exercise significant control over the company. This information is made publicly available via Companies House. The UK was a pioneer in establishing a public beneficial ownership register. Upcoming reforms through the Economic Crime and Corporate Transparency Bill will strengthen the verification of identities on the PSC register.
requirement: Companies must report individuals with significant control (>25%) to Companies House, with public access to this data.

This initiative aims to curb the use of UK property for laundering dirty money. As of 2023, compliance has been an issue, with many entities failing to report by the deadline. Enforcement actions are underway to ensure proper reporting.
requirement: Overseas entities owning UK property must disclose their beneficial owners to Companies House.

While this register is not public, it is accessible to law enforcement and individuals with a legitimate interest. The TRS plays a key role in increasing transparency in the trust sector and preventing misuse for illicit purposes.
requirement: Trusts must register their beneficial owners with HMRC. The information is accessible to law enforcement and those with a legitimate interest.

name: Significant Shareholder Notifications
description: The UK Listing Rules require companies listed on the stock exchange to notify the market whenever a shareholder crosses certain thresholds (e.g., 3%). This requirement is not specifically an anti-money laundering measure but enhances transparency in ownership, ensuring that major changes in corporate control are disclosed. It complements broader corporate transparency and shareholder reporting regulations.
requirement: Listed companies must notify the market of shareholders crossing certain ownership thresholds (3%).

name: Singapore - Register of Controllers
description: Since 2017, Singapore requires companies to maintain a Register of Controllers, which lists individuals or legal entities with significant control or interest in the company (generally >25% ownership or control). While the register is not publicly accessible, it must be provided to the government upon request. Additionally, trusts in Singapore must keep records of their beneficial owners.
requirement: Companies must maintain a Register of Controllers and provide it to the government upon request.

name: Hong Kong - Significant Controllers Register
description: Since 2018, Hong Kong has required companies to maintain a Significant Controllers Register, listing individuals or entities with more than 25% of shares, votes, or significant influence over the company. This register is not public but must be made available to law enforcement and relevant authorities.
requirement: Companies must maintain a Significant Controllers Register with individuals or entities having >25% shares or influence, available to law enforcement.

name: Australia - Corporate Transparency Reforms
description: Australia does not yet have a public UBO register for companies but requires shareholder disclosure for listed companies. The government is considering broader reforms to increase corporate transparency, including improvements for trusts and partnerships.
requirement: Australia requires shareholder disclosure for listed companies but has not yet introduced a public UBO register.

name: Offshore Financial Centers - Private BO Registers
description: Under international pressure, offshore financial centers such as the Cayman Islands and the British Virgin Islands have introduced private beneficial ownership registers. These registers are not public but are accessible to authorities through information exchange mechanisms. For example, the Cayman Islands requires filing BO information with the competent authority.
requirement: Private beneficial ownership registers accessible to authorities in offshore centers like the Cayman Islands and BVI.

name: Global Trend - Beneficial Ownership Transparency
description: Over 100 jurisdictions have committed to beneficial ownership (BO) transparency reforms, such as Ukraine with its public UBO register, Dubai (UAE) with regulations for reporting UBOs, and Nigeria (Companies and Allied Matters Act 2020) requiring BO disclosures. These initiatives align with FATF’s push to prevent the abuse of anonymous shell companies.
requirement: Multiple countries have introduced or committed to BO transparency reforms, aligning with FATF guidelines.

name: United Nations Security Council Sanctions
description: The United Nations Security Council (UNSC) imposes binding sanctions on member states under Chapter VII of the UN Charter. These sanctions include asset freezes, travel bans, and arms embargoes on individuals, entities, or countries such as North Korea, Iran, and ISIS/Al-Qaida. The UN maintains a Consolidated Sanctions List which is the primary reference for global compliance.
requirement: UN member states must comply with UNSC sanctions and freeze assets of individuals/entities on the UNSC sanctions list.

name: European Union Sanctions
description: The European Union implements all UN sanctions and also enforces its own autonomous sanctions through the Common Foreign and Security Policy. These sanctions include asset freezes, trade embargoes, and other measures, targeting entities like Russia, Syria, and terrorism-related groups. The EU Consolidated Financial Sanctions list is regularly updated.
requirement: EU persons and companies must comply with EU sanctions, including asset freezes and transaction bans with listed individuals/entities.

name: Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC) Sanctions - U.S.
description: The U.S. Treasury's Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC) administers various sanctions programs, including country-based and list-based sanctions (e.g., against Cuba, Iran, and counter-terrorism). The SDN List (Specially Designated Nationals) includes sanctioned individuals, entities, and assets, and U.S. persons are prohibited from transacting with these designees.
requirement: U.S. persons must freeze assets and refrain from dealing with individuals/entities listed on the SDN List. Non-U.S. companies may face secondary sanctions.

name: Canada - Special Economic Measures Act and UN Act
description: Canada administers sanctions primarily under the Special Economic Measures Act and the United Nations Act, aligning with UN, U.S., and EU sanctions. Canada can impose sanctions targeting individuals or entities associated with human rights violations, terrorism, or other threats to international peace.
requirement: Canadian entities and individuals must comply with Canadian sanctions and those listed under the Special Economic Measures Act.

name: China - Counter-Sanctions Law and Unreliable Entities List
description: China introduced a counter-sanctions law in 2021, creating an 'unreliable entities list' in response to foreign sanctions. Companies and individuals operating in China must be cautious about complying with foreign sanctions, as this may trigger countermeasures under China's new law. In 2023, China further strengthened its anti-espionage laws.
requirement: Chinese companies must avoid compliance with foreign sanctions that could trigger countermeasures, as defined by China's counter-sanctions law.

name: Global Magnitsky and Human Rights Sanctions
description: The U.S., UK, EU, and Canada have adopted the Global Magnitsky Human Rights Sanctions program, which targets individuals involved in human rights abuses, corruption, or grand corruption. These sanctions typically include asset freezes and travel bans, making it illegal to do business with such individuals.
requirement: Individuals listed under Magnitsky or Human Rights Sanctions are subject to asset freezes, travel bans, and transaction prohibitions.

name: United Nations Security Council Sanctions
description: The United Nations Security Council (UNSC) imposes binding sanctions on member states under Chapter VII of the UN Charter. These sanctions include asset freezes, travel bans, and arms embargoes on individuals, entities, or countries such as North Korea, Iran, and ISIS/Al-Qaida. The UN maintains a Consolidated Sanctions List which is the primary reference for global compliance.
requirement: UN member states must comply with UNSC sanctions and freeze assets of individuals/entities on the UNSC sanctions list.

name: European Union Sanctions
description: The European Union implements all UN sanctions and also enforces its own autonomous sanctions through the Common Foreign and Security Policy. These sanctions include asset freezes, trade embargoes, and other measures, targeting entities like Russia, Syria, and terrorism-related groups. The EU Consolidated Financial Sanctions list is regularly updated.
requirement: EU persons and companies must comply with EU sanctions, including asset freezes and transaction bans with listed individuals/entities.

name: Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC) Sanctions - U.S.
description: The U.S. Treasury's Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC) administers various sanctions programs, including country-based and list-based sanctions (e.g., against Cuba, Iran, and counter-terrorism). The SDN List (Specially Designated Nationals) includes sanctioned individuals, entities, and assets, and U.S. persons are prohibited from transacting with these designees.
requirement: U.S. persons must freeze assets and refrain from dealing with individuals/entities listed on the SDN List. Non-U.S. companies may face secondary sanctions.

name: Canada - Special Economic Measures Act and UN Act
description: Canada administers sanctions primarily under the Special Economic Measures Act and the United Nations Act, aligning with UN, U.S., and EU sanctions. Canada can impose sanctions targeting individuals or entities associated with human rights violations, terrorism, or other threats to international peace.
requirement: Canadian entities and individuals must comply with Canadian sanctions and those listed under the Special Economic Measures Act.

name: China - Counter-Sanctions Law and Unreliable Entities List
description: China introduced a counter-sanctions law in 2021, creating an 'unreliable entities list' in response to foreign sanctions. Companies and individuals operating in China must be cautious about complying with foreign sanctions, as this may trigger countermeasures under China's new law. In 2023, China further strengthened its anti-espionage laws.
requirement: Chinese companies must avoid compliance with foreign sanctions that could trigger countermeasures, as defined by China's counter-sanctions law.

name: Global Magnitsky and Human Rights Sanctions
description: The U.S., UK, EU, and Canada have adopted the Global Magnitsky Human Rights Sanctions program, which targets individuals involved in human rights abuses, corruption, or grand corruption. These sanctions typically include asset freezes and travel bans, making it illegal to do business with such individuals.
requirement: Individuals listed under Magnitsky or Human Rights Sanctions are subject to asset freezes, travel bans, and transaction prohibitions.

name: Transaction and Customer Screening
description: Financial institutions must screen customers and transactions against sanctions lists (e.g., UN, OFAC, EU) either in real time or at least daily. Matches require freezing of assets and mandatory reporting (e.g., OFAC blocking reports). This is a legal obligation under AML/CFT laws in most jurisdictions.
requirement: Implement real-time/daily screening against sanctions lists and act on matches.

name: Watchlists and Screening Tools
description: Organizations screen against a range of government lists (e.g., BIS Denied Persons List, U.S. State Dept Nonproliferation lists). Automated screening software flags potential matches, which must be reviewed manually to resolve false positives.
requirement: Deploy automated screening solutions and manual review for match resolution.

name: FATF High-Risk Jurisdictions Lists
description: FATF issues 'Black List' (call for action) and 'Gray List' (increased monitoring) to highlight countries with strategic AML/CFT deficiencies. Financial institutions must apply enhanced due diligence to transactions involving these jurisdictions. Many regulators enforce additional restrictions.
requirement: Apply enhanced due diligence to clients or transactions involving listed jurisdictions.

name: Proliferation Financing and Export Controls
description: In line with UNSC and FATF Recommendation 7, institutions must screen for WMD-related proliferation risks involving North Korea, Iran, and others. Export transactions must also comply with export control regulations. Screening for dual-use goods and sanctioned end-users is critical.
requirement: Monitor trade and financial transactions for proliferation risks and sanctioned end-users.

name: Ongoing Monitoring Procedures
description: Firms must rescreen clients and update sanctions data regularly (OFAC updates weekly). Monitoring includes detecting indirect exposure to sanctions (e.g. through intermediaries). Onboarding checks must be supplemented with periodic reviews and transaction screening.
requirement: Continuously monitor customers and transactions against evolving sanctions lists.

name: Sanctions Violations and Penalties
description: Breaches of sanctions laws can lead to severe penalties, including billions in fines and criminal prosecution. Notable cases include global banks fined for processing transactions for sanctioned entities or countries (e.g., Iran, Cuba). Sanctions compliance is highly enforced.
requirement: Ensure robust compliance to avoid financial and criminal penalties.

name: Wassenaar Arrangement
description: A voluntary, non-binding agreement among 42 countries to coordinate national export controls on conventional arms and dual-use goods and technologies. Members adopt common control lists (e.g. Munitions List, Dual-Use List) into national regulations, promoting global consistency in export restrictions.
requirement: Implement and maintain national export control lists aligned with Wassenaar standards.

name: Missile Technology Control Regime (MTCR)
description: An informal political understanding among 35 countries to restrict the proliferation of missile and unmanned aerial vehicle technology capable of delivering WMDs. Influences national licensing and control lists for missile-related exports.
requirement: Adopt national controls on MTCR-listed technologies and systems.

name: Arms Trade Treaty (ATT)
description: A UN treaty establishing common standards for international trade in conventional arms. Requires signatories to assess and block arms exports if there is a substantial risk of human rights abuse, terrorism, or organized crime. Applies to small arms, tanks, combat aircraft, etc.
requirement: Conduct export risk assessments and deny arms sales under certain humanitarian conditions.

name: World Trade Organization (WTO) Export Norms
description: Under GATT and WTO rules, countries must not impose arbitrary trade restrictions but may use security exceptions (e.g. GATT Article XXI) for justified export controls. Exporters must ensure their national policies align with WTO obligations.
requirement: Ensure export controls are WTO-compliant or properly justified under exceptions.

name: Free Trade Agreements (FTAs)
description: FTAs such as USMCA, CPTPP, and EU trade agreements provide reduced tariffs, digital trade protections, and trade facilitation obligations. Businesses must comply with origin rules, customs documentation, and digital trade clauses to benefit from FTAs lawfully.
requirement: Ensure accurate certification of origin, customs compliance, and use of digital trade protections where applicable.

name: Wassenaar Arrangement
description: A voluntary, non-binding agreement among 42 countries to coordinate national export controls on conventional arms and dual-use goods and technologies. Members adopt common control lists (e.g. Munitions List, Dual-Use List) into national regulations, promoting global consistency in export restrictions.
requirement: Implement and maintain national export control lists aligned with Wassenaar standards.

name: Missile Technology Control Regime (MTCR)
description: An informal political understanding among 35 countries to restrict the proliferation of missile and unmanned aerial vehicle technology capable of delivering WMDs. Influences national licensing and control lists for missile-related exports.
requirement: Adopt national controls on MTCR-listed technologies and systems.

name: Arms Trade Treaty (ATT)
description: A UN treaty establishing common standards for international trade in conventional arms. Requires signatories to assess and block arms exports if there is a substantial risk of human rights abuse, terrorism, or organized crime. Applies to small arms, tanks, combat aircraft, etc.
requirement: Conduct export risk assessments and deny arms sales under certain humanitarian conditions.

name: World Trade Organization (WTO) Export Norms
description: Under GATT and WTO rules, countries must not impose arbitrary trade restrictions but may use security exceptions (e.g. GATT Article XXI) for justified export controls. Exporters must ensure their national policies align with WTO obligations.
requirement: Ensure export controls are WTO-compliant or properly justified under exceptions.

name: Free Trade Agreements (FTAs)
description: FTAs such as USMCA, CPTPP, and EU trade agreements provide reduced tariffs, digital trade protections, and trade facilitation obligations. Businesses must comply with origin rules, customs documentation, and digital trade clauses to benefit from FTAs lawfully.
requirement: Ensure accurate certification of origin, customs compliance, and use of digital trade protections where applicable.

name: EU Dual-Use Regulation (Regulation (EU) 2021/821)
description: Governs export, brokering, transit, and transfer of dual-use goods, software, and technology from the EU. Aligned with Wassenaar Arrangement and other multilateral regimes. Requires licensing for certain destinations, end-uses, or technologies, including cyber-surveillance under human security considerations.
requirement: EU-based exporters must classify goods, assess licensing needs, and apply through their national export authority within the EU framework.

name: EU Common Position 2008/944/CFSP
description: Provides criteria for EU member states to assess arms export licenses. Focuses on regional stability, human rights, and international obligations. While military export control remains national, all EU states must align with this framework.
requirement: EU countries assess export license applications based on the Common Position criteria; reporting obligations also apply.

name: UK Strategic Export Controls / Export Control Order 2008
