description: Post-Brexit, the UK maintains its own export control system, closely aligned with the EU. The Order controls exports of military, dual-use, and other sensitive items under UK Strategic Export Control Lists. Licensing is required based on destination, use, and end-user.
requirement: UK exporters must check against the UK Control List and apply to the Export Control Joint Unit for licenses. Also includes general export licenses for lower-risk exports.

name: Japan – Foreign Exchange and Foreign Trade Act (FEFTA)
description: Japan’s primary export control law. Regulates export of dual-use and sensitive goods, particularly technology transfer. Aligned with multilateral regimes and includes strict screening obligations.
requirement: Japanese companies must conduct due diligence, screen for end-user and end-use, and apply for export licenses where required.

name: Canada – Export and Import Permits Act (EIPA)
description: Establishes control lists (Export Control List, Area Control List) governing exports of military and strategic goods. Also supports multilateral regimes like Wassenaar and MTCR. Includes controls on destinations like North Korea.
requirement: Canadian exporters must consult the ECL/ACL and apply for export permits via Global Affairs Canada.

name: Australia – Defense Trade Controls Act & Customs Act
description: Australia controls defense exports under the DTCA and strategic goods under the Customs Act. Covers tangible goods and intangible transfers (e.g., publication or sharing of controlled tech). Closely aligns with Wassenaar and other regimes.
requirement: Australian entities must assess whether goods or technologies fall under the Defense and Strategic Goods List and apply for licenses accordingly.

name: India – SCOMET List (Foreign Trade Policy)
description: India’s export control system governs dual-use goods via the SCOMET list. It requires licenses for items with military or proliferation potential. Additional restrictions apply for nuclear and defense items under separate laws.
requirement: Exporters must consult the SCOMET list and apply to DGFT for licenses for restricted items.

name: China – Export Control Law (2020)
description: China's unified export control law covers military, nuclear, dual-use, and other sensitive goods/technologies. Allows MOFCOM to impose controls based on national security or reciprocity. Includes licensing, entity lists, and prohibitions on certain tech exports.
requirement: Chinese companies must apply for licenses for listed items, comply with end-user/end-use controls, and respond to MOFCOM guidance and lists.

name: Data Localization & Cross-Border Data Transfer Regulations
description: Laws and regulations that require data (especially personal or sensitive data) to be stored and processed within a country’s borders, or that impose conditions on transferring such data abroad. Typically justified on privacy, national security, or regulatory access grounds.
requirement: Companies must assess whether they are subject to local data storage mandates and whether international transfers require safeguards, such as adequacy decisions, binding corporate rules, or standard contractual clauses.

name: CPTPP, USMCA – Digital Trade Provisions
description: These trade agreements prohibit requirements for local data storage or computing facilities as a condition for doing business, except where necessary for legitimate public policy objectives. They support cross-border data flows to promote digital trade.
requirement: Signatory countries must align national laws with agreement provisions; companies benefit from reduced legal barriers to cross-border data processing.

name: OECD Privacy Guidelines
description: Encourages free flow of personal data across borders with adequate protection, discouraging blanket localization mandates. Forms the foundation for many national privacy frameworks.
requirement: Companies and regulators are encouraged to adopt principles of proportionality, accountability, and interoperable data protection.

name: APEC Cross-Border Privacy Rules (CBPR) / Global CBPR Forum
description: A voluntary certification framework that enables personal data to flow among APEC economies through accredited businesses that implement privacy standards. Being expanded globally through the Global CBPR Forum.
jurisdiction: APEC members; Global CBPR Forum participants
requirement: Companies can be certified under CBPR, demonstrating compliance with baseline privacy requirements to enable data transfer among member economies.

name: Data Localization & Cross-Border Data Transfer Regulations
description: Laws and regulations that require data (especially personal or sensitive data) to be stored and processed within a country’s borders, or that impose conditions on transferring such data abroad. Typically justified on privacy, national security, or regulatory access grounds.
requirement: Companies must assess whether they are subject to local data storage mandates and whether international transfers require safeguards, such as adequacy decisions, binding corporate rules, or standard contractual clauses.

name: CPTPP, USMCA – Digital Trade Provisions
description: These trade agreements prohibit requirements for local data storage or computing facilities as a condition for doing business, except where necessary for legitimate public policy objectives. They support cross-border data flows to promote digital trade.
requirement: Signatory countries must align national laws with agreement provisions; companies benefit from reduced legal barriers to cross-border data processing.

name: OECD Privacy Guidelines
description: Encourages free flow of personal data across borders with adequate protection, discouraging blanket localization mandates. Forms the foundation for many national privacy frameworks.
requirement: Companies and regulators are encouraged to adopt principles of proportionality, accountability, and interoperable data protection.

name: APEC Cross-Border Privacy Rules (CBPR) / Global CBPR Forum
description: A voluntary certification framework that enables personal data to flow among APEC economies through accredited businesses that implement privacy standards. Being expanded globally through the Global CBPR Forum.
jurisdiction: APEC members; Global CBPR Forum participants
requirement: Companies can be certified under CBPR, demonstrating compliance with baseline privacy requirements to enable data transfer among member economies.

name: International Traffic in Arms Regulations (ITAR) – Data Localization
description: Requires technical data related to defense articles to be accessed only by U.S. persons unless a license is granted. Effectively mandates domestic storage or U.S.-only access for ITAR-controlled data.
requirement: Organizations handling ITAR data must restrict access to U.S. persons and may need to use U.S.-based cloud services (e.g., FedRAMP High). Unauthorized foreign access is treated as an export.

name: FedRAMP Cloud Requirements – Federal Data
description: Federal Risk and Authorization Management Program (FedRAMP) requires U.S. government data to be stored and processed in authorized cloud systems. High-impact data (e.g., defense or law enforcement) may require U.S.-based personnel and data centers.
requirement: Cloud providers serving U.S. federal agencies must meet FedRAMP security standards and may need to ensure data residency in the U.S., particularly for high-impact data classifications.

name: Clarifying Lawful Overseas Use of Data (CLOUD) Act
description: Grants U.S. law enforcement the authority to compel U.S.-based tech companies to provide data stored on servers outside the U.S., and enables bilateral agreements for cross-border data access.
requirement: U.S. service providers must comply with lawful data requests regardless of data’s physical location. Organizations abroad using U.S. providers must consider U.S. jurisdiction over stored data.

name: USMCA Article 19.12 – Cross-Border Data Transfers
description: Prohibits parties from requiring local storage of computing facilities for data processing, with an exception for financial services where access must be guaranteed to regulators.
requirement: Companies can transfer data freely unless regulators require local access in financial services. Supports U.S. anti-localization stance in digital trade policy.

name: HIPAA & State Healthcare Record Accessibility (e.g., Texas HB 300)
description: While HIPAA does not mandate data localization, it requires secure storage and privacy safeguards. Some states (like Texas) require that health data remain accessible and potentially recoverable locally.
requirement: Covered entities must ensure data protection under HIPAA. In Texas, health records must remain accessible in the state, creating practical local storage obligations.

name: China Personal Information Protection Law (PIPL)
description: Mandates data localization for critical infrastructure operators and large processors of personal data. Cross-border transfers require a security assessment, standard contracts, or certifications.
requirement: Entities handling large volumes of personal information or operating critical infrastructure must localize data or pass a security review before transferring data abroad.

name: China Data Security Law
description: Requires localization and export approval for 'important data' related to national security or public interest. Definitions vary by sector regulator.
requirement: Firms must store important data within China and receive regulator clearance to export it. Sector regulators determine what qualifies as important data.

name: Russia Personal Data Localization Law
description: Requires storage of Russian citizens' personal data in databases located within Russia. Primary data copy must be local, with limited external transfer.
requirement: All personal data on Russian citizens must first be collected and stored in Russia. External transfer permitted only if local copy exists.

name: India Digital Personal Data Protection Act (DPDP) 2023
description: Allows personal data transfers to countries on a government whitelist. Removed earlier data localization mandates found in draft versions.
requirement: Companies may transfer personal data to whitelisted jurisdictions but must ensure protection and regulatory access.

name: RBI Data Localization for Payment Systems
description: Mandates that all payment data be stored only in India. Applies to all system providers (e.g. Visa, Mastercard, PayPal).
requirement: Payment companies must ensure full data storage within India and must not mirror abroad without approval.

name: Vietnam Cybersecurity Law
description: Requires foreign technology firms to store data on Vietnamese users within Vietnam and maintain a local presence if providing key online services.
requirement: Critical platform providers must localize user data and set up local operations. Applies to personal, relationship, and usage data.

name: South Korea Electronic Financial Supervisory Regulations
description: Allows financial institutions to use foreign cloud services under certain security conditions. No broad data localization mandate.
requirement: Financial institutions may use overseas cloud providers with proper data protection and approval from the Financial Services Commission.

name: Japan Act on Protection of Personal Information (APPI)
description: Allows international data transfers under user consent or through adequacy safeguards. No general localization except for MyNumber identifiers.
requirement: Data transfers allowed with user consent or standard safeguards. MyNumber data (national ID) must be stored domestically.

name: Australia Security of Critical Infrastructure Act 2018 (amended 2022)
description: While not explicitly requiring localization, new amendments include risk management obligations for critical infrastructure, which may encourage local data handling.
requirement: Entities must implement risk plans for cyber and data security. Some sectors (e.g., healthcare) may be required to store sensitive data in Australia.

name: China Personal Information Protection Law (PIPL)
description: Mandates data localization for critical infrastructure operators and large processors of personal data. Cross-border transfers require a security assessment, standard contracts, or certifications.
requirement: Entities handling large volumes of personal information or operating critical infrastructure must localize data or pass a security review before transferring data abroad.

name: China Data Security Law
description: Requires localization and export approval for 'important data' related to national security or public interest. Definitions vary by sector regulator.
requirement: Firms must store important data within China and receive regulator clearance to export it. Sector regulators determine what qualifies as important data.

name: Russia Personal Data Localization Law
description: Requires storage of Russian citizens' personal data in databases located within Russia. Primary data copy must be local, with limited external transfer.
requirement: All personal data on Russian citizens must first be collected and stored in Russia. External transfer permitted only if local copy exists.

name: India Digital Personal Data Protection Act (DPDP) 2023
description: Allows personal data transfers to countries on a government whitelist. Removed earlier data localization mandates found in draft versions.
requirement: Companies may transfer personal data to whitelisted jurisdictions but must ensure protection and regulatory access.

name: RBI Data Localization for Payment Systems
description: Mandates that all payment data be stored only in India. Applies to all system providers (e.g. Visa, Mastercard, PayPal).
requirement: Payment companies must ensure full data storage within India and must not mirror abroad without approval.

name: Vietnam Cybersecurity Law
description: Requires foreign technology firms to store data on Vietnamese users within Vietnam and maintain a local presence if providing key online services.
requirement: Critical platform providers must localize user data and set up local operations. Applies to personal, relationship, and usage data.

name: South Korea Electronic Financial Supervisory Regulations
description: Allows financial institutions to use foreign cloud services under certain security conditions. No broad data localization mandate.
requirement: Financial institutions may use overseas cloud providers with proper data protection and approval from the Financial Services Commission.

name: Japan Act on Protection of Personal Information (APPI)
description: Allows international data transfers under user consent or through adequacy safeguards. No general localization except for MyNumber identifiers.
requirement: Data transfers allowed with user consent or standard safeguards. MyNumber data (national ID) must be stored domestically.

name: Australia Security of Critical Infrastructure Act 2018 (amended 2022)
description: While not explicitly requiring localization, new amendments include risk management obligations for critical infrastructure, which may encourage local data handling.
requirement: Entities must implement risk plans for cyber and data security. Some sectors (e.g., healthcare) may be required to store sensitive data in Australia.

name: EU General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)
description: Prohibits the transfer of personal data outside the EU unless the receiving country has adequate data protection, or through specific transfer mechanisms like Standard Contractual Clauses (SCCs).
requirement: Transfers require adequate protection or specific mechanisms (e.g., SCCs, Binding Corporate Rules).

name: China Personal Information Protection Law (PIPL)
description: Mandates that critical infrastructure operators and large data processors store personal data within China, or undergo a security assessment to export it.
requirement: Personal data must be stored within China or undergo security assessment for export.

name: India Data Protection Bill (DPDP Act 2023)
description: Provides a framework for data localization, allowing cross-border transfers only to countries with adequate protection. Some sectors, like finance, require local data storage.
requirement: Cross-border data transfers allowed to whitelisted countries, with exceptions for specific sectors.

name: Brazil General Data Protection Law (LGPD)
description: Regulates data protection in Brazil, allows international data transfers based on adequacy decisions or through mechanisms like Standard Contractual Clauses.
requirement: Transfers permitted to countries deemed to have adequate protections or with prior, informed consent from the data subject.

name: Russia Personal Data Law (2015)
description: Requires personal data of Russian citizens to be stored in Russia, but allows data transfers under certain conditions if primary data is kept locally.
requirement: Primary data must be stored in Russia, with allowed transfers under specific conditions.

name: Sarbanes-Oxley Act (SOX)
description: U.S. law requiring public companies to maintain effective internal controls over financial reporting. Often relevant for financial system vendors.
requirement: Management and auditors must attest to the effectiveness of internal controls. Commonly assessed using COSO framework.

name: Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act (GLBA) – Safeguards Rule
description: U.S. law requiring financial institutions to implement security programs to protect customer data.
requirement: Financial institutions must have a written information security plan to protect customer information.

name: Dodd-Frank Act
description: Comprehensive U.S. financial reform law covering consumer protection, trading, capital requirements, and risk controls.
requirement: Includes the Volcker Rule and CFPB rules on fair lending and UDAAP; applies to banks and financial services firms.

name: Basel III
description: Global standard on capital adequacy and liquidity for banks, issued by the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision.
requirement: Banks must maintain minimum capital ratios and undergo stress tests. Enforced through national regulators.

name: Solvency II
description: EU framework for insurance regulation covering capital requirements, governance, and disclosure obligations.
requirement: Insurers must calculate Solvency Capital Requirements and ensure adequate governance and reporting.

name: MiFID II / MiFIR
description: EU laws governing trading, investor protection, and transparency in financial markets.
requirement: Requires best execution, timestamping of trades, and transparency for trading venues and investment firms.

name: EMIR (EU) & Dodd-Frank Title VII (US)
description: Rules requiring clearing, reporting, and risk mitigation for OTC derivatives in EU and US markets.
requirement: Mandates central clearing and reporting of derivative contracts to reduce systemic risk.

name: PCI-DSS (Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard)
description: Standard for securing credit card data, enforced by payment card networks like Visa and Mastercard.
requirement: Entities that process, store, or transmit cardholder data must comply with 12 security requirements.

name: PSD2 & Open Banking
description: European law promoting innovation and competition in payments, requiring strong customer authentication and open APIs.
requirement: Requires SCA and mandates that banks open customer account access to licensed third parties.

name: SWIFT Customer Security Programme (CSP)
description: Security controls required of financial institutions using the SWIFT network to prevent cyber fraud.
requirement: Banks must comply with SWIFT's mandatory and advisory security controls.

name: HIPAA (Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act)
description: U.S. law regulating the privacy and security of Protected Health Information (PHI). Applies to healthcare providers, insurers, and business associates.
requirement: Covered entities must implement safeguards for PHI, conduct training, and sign Business Associate Agreements.

name: HITECH Act (Health Information Technology for Economic and Clinical Health Act)
description: Strengthens HIPAA by mandating breach notifications and extending provisions to business associates. Encourages secure adoption of electronic health records.
requirement: Requires notification of data breaches and promotes meaningful use of EHR systems with security measures.

name: 21 CFR Part 11
description: FDA regulation governing the use of electronic records and electronic signatures in pharmaceutical and medical device companies to ensure integrity and trustworthiness.
requirement: Electronic records must meet criteria for audit trails, validation, security, and signature authenticity.

name: GDPR (EU) – Health Data
description: EU regulation that classifies health data as a special category, requiring stricter legal bases for processing.
requirement: Processing requires explicit consent or another legal justification. May also require certified data hosting in some countries.

name: ICH GxP (GCP, GLP, GMP)
description: Guidelines for pharmaceutical quality and compliance: Good Clinical Practice (GCP), Good Laboratory Practice (GLP), Good Manufacturing Practice (GMP).
requirement: Vendors and regulated entities must comply with GxP standards to ensure data integrity and product quality.

name: WHO Guidelines & National Healthcare Laws
description: Country-specific laws and WHO guidance on patient privacy, telemedicine, and healthcare data handling.
requirement: Healthcare providers and AI vendors must comply with local data privacy laws and WHO-aligned best practices (e.g., Singapore PDPA & MOH).

name: HIPAA (Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act)
description: U.S. law regulating the privacy and security of Protected Health Information (PHI). Applies to healthcare providers, insurers, and business associates.
requirement: Covered entities must implement safeguards for PHI, conduct training, and sign Business Associate Agreements.

name: HITECH Act (Health Information Technology for Economic and Clinical Health Act)
description: Strengthens HIPAA by mandating breach notifications and extending provisions to business associates. Encourages secure adoption of electronic health records.
requirement: Requires notification of data breaches and promotes meaningful use of EHR systems with security measures.

name: 21 CFR Part 11
description: FDA regulation governing the use of electronic records and electronic signatures in pharmaceutical and medical device companies to ensure integrity and trustworthiness.
requirement: Electronic records must meet criteria for audit trails, validation, security, and signature authenticity.

name: GDPR (EU) – Health Data
description: EU regulation that classifies health data as a special category, requiring stricter legal bases for processing.
requirement: Processing requires explicit consent or another legal justification. May also require certified data hosting in some countries.

name: ICH GxP (GCP, GLP, GMP)
description: Guidelines for pharmaceutical quality and compliance: Good Clinical Practice (GCP), Good Laboratory Practice (GLP), Good Manufacturing Practice (GMP).
requirement: Vendors and regulated entities must comply with GxP standards to ensure data integrity and product quality.

name: WHO Guidelines & National Healthcare Laws
description: Country-specific laws and WHO guidance on patient privacy, telemedicine, and healthcare data handling.
requirement: Healthcare providers and AI vendors must comply with local data privacy laws and WHO-aligned best practices (e.g., Singapore PDPA & MOH).

name: FERPA
description: The Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act protects privacy of student education records at schools receiving federal funds.
requirement: Schools must have written permission to release records, and students/parents have rights to access and correct records.

name: COPPA
description: For EdTech serving children under 13 (e.g. online learning platforms in elementary schools), COPPA applies (parental consent for data).
requirement: Parental consent is required before collecting data from children under 13.

name: GDPR & Education
description: GDPR covers schools in the EU as data controllers, with children’s data receiving special protections and age-of-consent defined by each country (typically 13-16).
requirement: Schools must comply with GDPR including protections for children's data, with national variations for age-of-consent.

name: State Student Privacy Laws
description: Many US states passed additional laws (e.g. California SOPIPA) restricting EdTech companies from using student data for advertising and other non-educational purposes.
requirement: EdTech vendors must comply with state-specific student privacy laws, often prohibiting data use for advertising.

name: ISO 27018
description: A code of practice for protecting personal data in the cloud, often adopted by EdTech to demonstrate privacy controls.
requirement: Cloud providers handling personal data, including EdTech vendors, should adopt ISO 27018 to demonstrate strong privacy protections.

name: FedRAMP
description: Federal Risk and Authorization Management Program: a framework that cloud services must meet to be used by U.S. federal agencies. It has impact levels (Low, Moderate, High) with NIST 800-53 based controls. A vendor selling cloud to US agencies will need FedRAMP Authorization.
requirement: Cloud service providers must obtain FedRAMP Authorization to operate within U.S. federal agencies, adhering to NIST 800-53 controls.

name: NIST SP 800-171
description: NIST 800-171 outlines security requirements for protecting Controlled Unclassified Information (CUI) in non-federal systems. It's required by DFARS clause for defense contractors handling CUI.
requirement: Defense contractors must implement NIST SP 800-171 controls to protect CUI as mandated by DFARS.

name: CMMC
description: The Cybersecurity Maturity Model Certification (CMMC) certifies defense contractors at Levels 1–3 based on NIST 800-171 and additional practices, ensuring protection of CUI.
requirement: Defense contractors must achieve the appropriate CMMC level certification to bid on DoD contracts involving CUI.

name: ITAR
description: International Traffic in Arms Regulations control the export and import of defense-related articles and services, requiring compliance for defense contractors.
requirement: Entities must comply with ITAR regulations when exporting or importing defense-related articles and services.

name: EAR
description: Export Administration Regulations govern the export of dual-use items, requiring compliance for entities dealing with such technologies.
requirement: Entities must adhere to EAR when exporting dual-use items, ensuring they do not contribute to the proliferation of weapons or other threats.

name: False Claims Act
description: The False Claims Act imposes liability on individuals and companies who defraud governmental programs, including defense contracts.
requirement: Contractors must avoid submitting false claims to the government; violations can lead to significant penalties.

name: Procurement Integrity Act
description: The Act prohibits the release of source selection and contractor bid or proposal information, ensuring fairness in federal procurement.
requirement: Individuals involved in federal procurement must not disclose or obtain procurement-sensitive information.

name: Anti-Kickback Act
description: The Act prohibits offering, accepting, or soliciting kickbacks in connection with federal contracts, promoting ethical practices.
requirement: Contractors must not engage in kickback activities; compliance programs are often required to prevent violations.

name: CFIUS
description: The Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States reviews foreign investments for national security implications.
requirement: Certain foreign investments must be reviewed and approved by CFIUS to ensure they do not threaten national security.

name: UK NSI Act
description: The UK's National Security and Investment Act allows the government to scrutinize and intervene in business transactions to protect national security.
requirement: Businesses must notify the UK government of certain transactions that could pose national security risks.

name: EU FDI Screening
description: The EU framework for screening foreign direct investments aims to protect security and public order in member states.
requirement: Member states must screen foreign investments for potential risks to security or public order, coordinating with the European Commission.

name: NERC CIP
description: Critical Infrastructure Protection standards for North American electric utilities, covering cybersecurity for power grids.
requirement: Vendors supplying to the energy sector may need to align with NERC CIP requirements to ensure the security of the bulk electric system.

name: EPA Environmental Compliance
description: Regulations enforced by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency to ensure environmental protection, including permits for factories and compliance with chemical regulations.
requirement: Factories and manufacturing entities must obtain necessary environmental permits and comply with EPA regulations such as REACH and RoHS.

name: REACH
description: Registration, Evaluation, Authorisation and Restriction of Chemicals (REACH) is the main EU law to protect human health and the environment from chemical risks.
requirement: Companies manufacturing or importing chemicals into the EU must register substances and ensure safe use according to REACH regulations.

name: RoHS Directive
description: Restriction of Hazardous Substances Directive restricts the use of specific hazardous materials found in electrical and electronic products.
requirement: Manufacturers must ensure their electrical and electronic equipment does not contain restricted hazardous substances beyond specified limits.

name: Equator Principles
description: A risk management framework adopted by financial institutions for determining, assessing, and managing environmental and social risk in projects.
requirement: Financial institutions must apply the Equator Principles to projects to ensure environmental and social risks are properly managed.

name: IFC Performance Standards
description: Standards established by the International Finance Corporation to manage environmental and social risks and impacts in development projects.
requirement: Organizations receiving financing from IFC must adhere to these standards to ensure sustainable and socially responsible development.

name: ISO/IEC 27001
description: International standard for Information Security Management Systems (ISMS), outlining requirements for establishing, implementing, maintaining, and continually improving an information security management system.
requirement: Organizations can get certified to ISO 27001 to show they have a systematic approach to securing data, covering risk assessment, controls, incident response, etc.

name: SOC 2
description: Audit report standard for service organizations, evaluating controls relevant to Security, Availability, Processing Integrity, Confidentiality, and Privacy (the Trust Services Criteria).
requirement: A SOC 2 Type II report (audit over 6-12 months) is a common ask in tech vendor due diligence, especially for cloud/SaaS providers.

name: NIST Cybersecurity Framework (CSF)
description: Voluntary framework for managing cybersecurity risk, structured around Identify, Protect, Detect, Respond, Recover functions.
requirement: Widely used internationally as a best practice baseline for cybersecurity risk management.

name: CIS Controls
description: A prioritized list of cybersecurity best practices (currently 18 controls) to help organizations strengthen their cybersecurity posture.
requirement: Organizations use CIS Controls as a practical guide to harden systems and improve cybersecurity defenses.

name: OWASP Top 10
description: A widely recognized list of the top 10 web application security risks published by the Open Web Application Security Project.
requirement: A checklist for developers to avoid common vulnerabilities such as injection, XSS, etc.

name: CSA STAR / CAIQ
description: Cloud Security Alliance’s Security, Trust & Assurance Registry (STAR) is a certification for cloud providers. The Consensus Assessments Initiative Questionnaire (CAIQ) is a detailed questionnaire covering a cloud provider’s security controls.
requirement: Cloud providers can achieve STAR certification and complete the CAIQ to demonstrate their security posture.

name: Shared Assessments SIG
description: An industry-standard questionnaire used in third-party risk assessments, covering 18 risk domains such as information security, privacy, business continuity, etc.
requirement: Companies might ask a vendor to complete a SIG questionnaire to assess their risk posture.

name: ITIL / COBIT
description: Frameworks for IT service management (ITIL) and IT governance (COBIT). Not compliance per se, but sometimes referenced in questionnaires related to IT controls and processes.
requirement: Organizations may reference ITIL and COBIT frameworks to demonstrate adherence to best practices in IT service management and governance.

name: CSA Controls Matrix & NIST 800-53
description: CSA’s Cloud Controls Matrix (CCM) maps many standards including ISO, NIST, COBIT, PCI, etc. NIST 800-53 outlines security and privacy controls for federal information systems.
requirement: Vendors providing cloud services to the U.S. government might adhere to NIST 800-53 controls (required by FedRAMP Moderate/High).

name: BSI IT-Grundschutz
description: A national standard for information security developed by the German Federal Office for Information Security (BSI).
requirement: Organizations in Germany or working with German government entities might adhere to BSI IT-Grundschutz standards.

name: ISO 14001 / ISO 45001
description: ISO 14001 is an international standard for environmental management systems, and ISO 45001 is an international standard for occupational health and safety management systems.
requirement: Organizations can get certified to ISO 14001 and ISO 45001 to demonstrate their commitment to environmental management and occupational health and safety.

name: Trust and Transparency Initiatives
description: Many tech companies maintain Trust Centers (web portals) where they list their certifications (ISO, SOC 2, PCI, etc.), policies, and audit reports under NDA.
requirement: Organizations are encouraged to centralize compliance information for customers through Trust and Transparency Initiatives.

name: Certifications
description: Sector-specific certifications like PCI QSA (assessors), HITRUST CSF (common security framework mainly in healthcare), TL 9000 (telecom quality), etc., demonstrate compliance with best practices.
requirement: Organizations can obtain sector-specific certifications to demonstrate their adherence to industry standards and best practices.

name: ISO 22301 for Business Continuity Management
description: A framework for business continuity management to ensure organizations can continue operating during and after a disaster.
requirement: Organizations must have a certified BCMS or conduct regular disaster recovery tests to ensure business continuity.

name: Ethics and Social Compliance – JSRS, Ecovadis, SA8000
description: Industry consortia questionnaires like the Joint Supplier Registration System (JSRS) and Ecovadis ratings for CSR or SA8000 for labor conditions.
requirement: Vendors may need to provide evidence of compliance with specific ethical, social, and labor standards, depending on the context.

name: GDPR (EU)
description: Comprehensive regulation that standardizes data protection laws across all EU member states, giving individuals extensive rights over their personal data including access, erasure, and portability. Features strict consent requirements, mandatory breach notifications, and potential fines of up to 4% of global revenue for violations.
requirement: Organizations must comply with strict data protection regulations, providing rights to individuals and ensuring adequate data protection measures.

name: UK GDPR & Data Protection Act 2018
description: The UK's adaptation of GDPR principles following Brexit, maintaining essentially the same protections and requirements as EU GDPR while establishing the UK's independent data protection framework. Includes specific provisions for law enforcement and intelligence services data processing.
requirement: Data protection principles similar to EU GDPR, with additional provisions specific to UK law enforcement and intelligence.

name: PDPA (Singapore)
description: Governs the collection, use, disclosure, and care of personal data by organizations through a consent-based framework. Requires organizations to appoint data protection officers and includes a Do Not Call Registry for marketing communications. Recently amended to include mandatory breach notifications and data portability provisions.
requirement: Organizations must obtain consent for data collection, appoint data protection officers, and comply with data portability and breach notification rules.

name: PIPL (China)
description: China's first comprehensive personal information protection law, enforcing strict rules on data processing activities both inside China and extraterritorially. Features localization requirements for certain data, mandatory security assessments for cross-border transfers, and severe penalties including business suspension and personal liability for executives.
requirement: Organizations must comply with strict data localization, processing, and security requirements, with penalties for non-compliance.

name: DPDP Act (India 2023)
description: India's newly enacted data protection framework replacing earlier draft bills, focusing on digital personal data. Introduces data fiduciary responsibilities, legitimate use requirements, and establishes a Data Protection Board. Contains significant provisions for cross-border data flows and includes potential penalties of up to 250 million rupees for serious violations.
requirement: Organizations must follow data fiduciary responsibilities and consent requirements, with significant provisions for cross-border data transfers.

name: LGPD (Brazil)
description: Brazil's General Data Protection Law closely follows GDPR's model with ten legal bases for processing, data subject rights, and appointment of DPOs. Enforced by the Brazilian Data Protection Authority (ANPD) with sanctions including warnings, fines up to 2% of Brazilian revenue, and data processing prohibitions.
requirement: Organizations must comply with processing rules, data subject rights, and DPO appointment, with penalties for non-compliance.

name: PDPO (Hong Kong)
description: Hong Kong's Personal Data (Privacy) Ordinance established six data protection principles covering collection, accuracy, retention, usage, security, and access. Recently strengthened with anti-doxxing provisions following social unrest and features an active Privacy Commissioner's office with investigation and enforcement powers.
requirement: Organizations must adhere to six data protection principles and comply with privacy regulations enforced by the Privacy Commissioner.

name: Privacy Act (Australia)
description: Australia's foundational privacy law containing 13 Australian Privacy Principles governing the handling of personal information by government agencies and larger businesses. Enforced by the Office of the Australian Information Commissioner with serious violation penalties up to AUD 2.1 million for corporations.
requirement: Organizations must comply with 13 privacy principles, with penalties for violations enforced by the Australian Information Commissioner.

name: Personal Information Protection Acts (Asia)
description: Various Asian nations have developed robust privacy frameworks: South Korea's PIPA is one of Asia's strictest with specific consent and security requirements; Thailand's PDPA introduced GDPR-like provisions with extraterritorial application; Japan's APPI requires privacy policies and recently strengthened international transfer restrictions and penalties.
requirement: Countries such as South Korea, Thailand, and Japan have specific data protection laws governing consent, security, and international data transfers.

name: FATF Recommendations
description: International standards established by the Financial Action Task Force comprising 40 recommendations that serve as the global benchmark for anti-money laundering (AML) and counter-terrorist financing (CFT) measures. These recommendations require countries to implement risk-based approaches to financial crime, conduct enhanced customer due diligence, maintain comprehensive transaction monitoring systems, and establish Financial Intelligence Units for suspicious transaction analysis.
requirement: Countries must implement risk-based AML/CFT measures, including customer due diligence, monitoring systems, and financial intelligence units.

name: Bank Secrecy Act (US)
description: Cornerstone of U.S. AML legislation requiring financial institutions to implement robust AML compliance programs including customer identification procedures, transaction monitoring, and filing of Currency Transaction Reports for transactions exceeding $10,000. Complemented by the USA PATRIOT Act's enhanced due diligence requirements and FinCEN's enforcement authority with civil and criminal penalties for non-compliance.
requirement: Financial institutions must maintain AML programs, conduct customer due diligence, monitor transactions, and report suspicious activities.

name: EU Anti-Money Laundering Directives (4th, 5th, 6th)
description: Progressive regulatory framework continually strengthening AML controls across the European Union. The 4th Directive introduced risk assessments and beneficial ownership registers; the 5th extended regulations to virtual currencies and prepaid cards while enhancing transparency requirements; the 6th harmonized money laundering criminal offenses and established minimum imprisonment penalties across member states.
requirement: AML measures must be implemented across EU member states, including risk assessments, transparency requirements, and criminal penalties.

name: Proceeds of Crime Act (UK)
description: Comprehensive UK legislation establishing criminal offenses for money laundering activities including concealing, arranging, and acquiring criminal property. Creates mandatory suspicious activity reporting obligations for regulated sectors with criminal liability for failure to disclose. Grants authorities extensive powers for civil recovery, cash seizure, and confiscation of criminal assets.
requirement: Organizations must report suspicious activities, and authorities have powers to seize criminal assets and impose penalties.

name: PCMLTFA (Canada)
description: The Proceeds of Crime (Money Laundering) and Terrorist Financing Act establishes Canada's AML/CFT regime requiring reporting entities to implement compliance programs, conduct customer identification, maintain records, and report suspicious and large cash transactions to FINTRAC. Recent amendments extend coverage to virtual currency exchanges and foreign money services businesses operating in Canada.
requirement: Reporting entities must implement compliance programs, conduct customer identification, and report suspicious activities.

name: Regional AML Laws (Asia & Pacific)
description: Major Asian and Pacific jurisdictions have established comprehensive AML frameworks: China's Anti-Money Laundering Law grants extensive powers to the People's Bank of China; Hong Kong's AMLO imposes strict customer due diligence requirements; Singapore's Corruption, Drug Trafficking and Other Serious Crimes Act carries severe penalties including imprisonment; Japan's Act on Prevention of Transfer of Criminal Proceeds focuses on financial institution obligations; India's Prevention of Money Laundering Act combines criminal provisions with regulatory requirements; Australia's AML/CTF Act employs a risk-based approach with AUSTRAC as its dedicated financial intelligence unit.
requirement: AML measures vary by country but generally include customer due diligence, transaction monitoring, and reporting obligations.
official_url: https://www.pbc.gov.cn (China), https://www.fstb.gov.hk (Hong Kong), https://www.singaporecustoms.gov.sg (Singapore), https://www.fsa.go.jp (Japan), https://www.pmla.gov.in (India), https://www.austrac.gov.au (Australia)

name: Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (FCPA)
description: The Foreign Corrupt Practices Act features dual provisions prohibiting payments to foreign government officials to obtain business advantages and mandating publicly-traded companies maintain accurate books and records with effective internal accounting controls. Enforced by both the DOJ and SEC with extraterritorial jurisdiction and penalties including criminal fines, imprisonment, and disgorgement of profits.
requirement: Corporations must prohibit foreign bribery and maintain accurate records and internal controls.

name: UK Bribery Act
description: Among the world's strictest anti-corruption legislation with four primary offenses: bribing another person, receiving bribes, bribing foreign officials, and failing to prevent bribery. Features strict liability, no facilitation payment exemptions, and applies to both public and private sectors.
requirement: Organizations must implement adequate procedures to prevent bribery or face strict liability and severe penalties.

name: OECD Anti-Bribery Convention
description: Legally binding international agreement requiring 44 signatory countries to criminalize bribery of foreign officials in international business. Includes corporate liability, mutual legal assistance, and peer review monitoring.
requirement: Member countries must criminalize bribery of foreign officials and implement enforcement mechanisms.

name: United Nations Convention Against Corruption (UNCAC)
description: The only legally binding universal anti-corruption instrument, covering prevention, criminalization, international cooperation, and asset recovery. Applies to both public and private sector corruption and promotes technical assistance and information exchange.
requirement: Parties must implement preventive, legal, and cooperative measures to combat corruption.

name: European National Anti-Corruption Laws
description: France's Sapin II mandates corporate compliance programs under the AFA; Germany's Criminal Code criminalizes public and commercial bribery, enabling corporate liability and asset confiscation under the Administrative Offenses Act.
requirement: Organizations must maintain anti-corruption programs; violations lead to corporate liability, fines, and confiscation.
effective_date: France: 2016-12-09, Germany: ongoing since amendments through 2021

name: Corruption of Foreign Public Officials Act (CFPOA)
description: Canada's CFPOA criminalizes bribery of foreign public officials. Penalties include unlimited corporate fines and imprisonment for individuals. Amendments removed facilitation exceptions and introduced books and records requirements.
requirement: Companies and individuals must not bribe foreign officials and must maintain accurate records.

name: Asia-Pacific Anti-Corruption Laws
description: Includes China's Criminal Law Articles 385-395 and Anti-Unfair Competition Law; India’s Prevention of Corruption Act; Singapore’s Prevention of Corruption Act; Japan’s Unfair Competition Prevention Act and Penal Code; South Korea’s Improper Solicitation and Graft Act. These laws criminalize bribery and impose compliance requirements with varying penalties, including imprisonment and corporate sanctions.
jurisdiction: China, India, Singapore, Japan, South Korea
requirement: Organizations and individuals must comply with national anti-bribery laws, which often include reporting, due diligence, and recordkeeping.
effective_date: Varies by country: China (1997), India (1988), Singapore (1960), Japan (2001), South Korea (2016)
official_url: https://www.spp.gov.cn (China), https://legislative.gov.in (India), https://sso.agc.gov.sg (Singapore), https://www.moj.go.jp (Japan), https://www.acrc.go.kr (South Korea)

name: FATF Recommendations 24 & 25
description: Core international standards requiring transparency about beneficial ownership of legal persons and arrangements. Countries must maintain accurate and timely information accessible to competent authorities, with the 2022 revisions introducing central registries and stronger verification measures to counter illicit financial activity.
requirement: Countries must adopt multi-pronged approaches to beneficial ownership transparency including registries and verification mechanisms.

name: Corporate Transparency Act (CTA)
description: Landmark U.S. law requiring certain corporations, LLCs, and similar entities to report beneficial ownership information to FinCEN. Targets individuals with 25% ownership or substantial control, with exemptions for regulated entities. Non-compliance carries criminal and civil penalties.
requirement: Covered entities must report beneficial ownership details to FinCEN or face penalties.

name: EU Anti-Money Laundering Directives (AMLDs)
description: Successive EU AMLDs have introduced and expanded beneficial ownership requirements: central registers in the 4th AMLD, public access in the 5th, and enhanced verification in the 6th. Requirements vary across member states but include 25%+ ownership thresholds and cross-border data sharing.
requirement: Legal entities must register beneficial ownership with national registries, with increasing verification and access obligations.

name: UK People with Significant Control (PSC) Register
description: Public registry requiring UK companies to disclose individuals with significant control—defined by ownership thresholds or influence over decision-making—to Companies House. Includes criminal liability for non-compliance and requires annual confirmation.
requirement: UK companies must identify and report PSCs with more than 25% control or significant influence.

name: UK Register of Overseas Entities
description: Established under the Economic Crime (Transparency and Enforcement) Act 2022, it requires foreign entities owning UK land/property to disclose beneficial owners to Companies House. Non-compliance restricts property transactions and can trigger criminal penalties.
requirement: Foreign entities must declare beneficial ownership before engaging in UK property transactions.

name: Regional Ownership Transparency Laws
description: Various jurisdictions mandate beneficial ownership transparency: Singapore's Register of Controllers, Hong Kong's Significant Controllers Register, Canada's CBCA amendments, and Australia’s proposed register. These laws vary in access, thresholds, and verification requirements but aim to deter misuse of corporate structures.
requirement: Companies must maintain records of individuals with significant control and provide access to authorities; some jurisdictions also require public disclosure.
effective_date: Varies by country: Singapore (2017), Hong Kong (2018), Canada (2019), Australia (proposed)

name: UN Security Council Sanctions
description: Legally binding sanctions measures adopted under Chapter VII of the UN Charter. These include asset freezes, travel bans, and embargoes implemented through Security Council Resolutions. All 193 UN member states are required to implement these sanctions domestically.
requirement: Member states must implement UN sanctions measures into their national legal frameworks.

name: EU Sanctions
description: The EU enforces both UN-aligned and independent sanctions, including asset freezes, travel bans, and sector-specific restrictions. Sanctions target human rights violators, cyber attackers, and regimes using chemical weapons. Adopted via Council decisions and directly applicable regulations.
requirement: Member states must enforce EU sanctions which apply directly and require national implementation support.

name: OFAC Sanctions (US)
description: Administered by the Office of Foreign Assets Control, the U.S. maintains comprehensive sanctions programs with global reach. Includes SDN List, Sectoral Sanctions, and country-specific programs. Violations carry strict liability and hefty penalties, enforced under the '50% Rule'.
requirement: U.S. persons and global actors dealing with U.S. financial systems must comply with OFAC sanctions lists and restrictions.

name: UK Sanctions Framework
description: Post-Brexit UK sanctions regime governed by the Sanctions and Anti-Money Laundering Act 2018. Administered by OFSI, includes UK Sanctions List, rapid designation authority, and civil/criminal penalties for non-compliance.
requirement: UK entities must comply with sanctions designations, implement asset freezes, and report breaches to OFSI.

name: FATF Recommendation 12 – PEP Screening
description: Requires financial institutions to apply enhanced due diligence to politically exposed persons (PEPs), including identification, senior management approval, and verification of source of wealth. Applies to foreign, domestic, and international organization PEPs.
requirement: Identify and monitor PEPs and related persons with enhanced due diligence and risk-based approach.

name: Regional Sanctions Regimes
description: Canada (Special Economic Measures Act), Australia (DFAT autonomous sanctions), and Japan (Foreign Exchange and Foreign Trade Act) maintain sanctions programs with varying penalties. These often align with UN or allied frameworks but maintain independent designation authority.
requirement: Financial institutions and businesses must comply with national sanctions lists and controls.

name: Screening and Compliance Practices
description: Entities must screen clients and transactions against sanctions lists, PEP databases, and adverse media using automated and manual methods. Includes real-time monitoring, periodic rescreening, and false positive resolution. Key to regulatory compliance and audit readiness.
requirement: Implement layered, risk-based screening systems for sanctions, PEPs, and adverse media with documentation and audit trails.

name: Export Administration Regulations (EAR)
description: Administered by the U.S. Bureau of Industry and Security (BIS), the EAR controls exports, reexports, and transfers of commercial and dual-use items. Regulates based on ECCNs, destination, end-users, and end-use, with extraterritorial application for US-origin content. Expanded to address emerging technologies and geopolitical concerns.
requirement: Exporters must determine item classification and obtain licenses when applicable, screen end-users and destinations, and comply with reexport rules.

name: International Traffic in Arms Regulations (ITAR)
description: Administered by the U.S. Department of State, ITAR governs the export of defense articles and services listed on the USML. Requires DDTC registration, licenses for exports, strict recordkeeping, and imposes criminal penalties for violations.
requirement: Entities involved with USML items must register with DDTC and obtain proper authorization for export activities.

name: EU Dual-Use Regulation (Regulation 2021/821)
description: Establishes EU-wide controls for export, brokering, transit, and transfer of dual-use items. Harmonizes control lists, introduces controls for cyber-surveillance technologies, and requires Internal Compliance Programs (ICPs).
requirement: Exporters must classify items and apply for licenses when necessary, implement ICPs, and ensure end-use compliance.

name: UK Export Control Order 2008 (as amended)
description: Post-Brexit export control regime administered by the UK's ECJU. Covers military and dual-use items with controls on intangible transfers and provisions for academic research. Licensing decisions are guided by national security and human rights criteria.
requirement: Exporters must determine item classification under UK control lists and obtain appropriate export licenses.

name: Regional Export Controls
description: Major jurisdictions operate export controls with unique features: China’s 2020 Export Control Law applies extraterritorially and includes retaliation provisions; Japan controls strategic goods through FEFTA; Singapore and South Korea impose rigorous licensing and transit rules.
requirement: Exporters must comply with national licensing, end-use screening, and item classification rules, often with extraterritorial elements.

name: US Anti-Boycott Regulations
description: Prohibits U.S. persons from participating in unsanctioned foreign boycotts (e.g., Arab League boycott of Israel). Requires reporting boycott requests, prohibits providing boycott-related info, and imposes civil/criminal penalties and tax consequences.
requirement: Companies must reject and report boycott requests, avoid prohibited agreements, and maintain compliance records.

name: Customs and Import Regulations
description: Governs import compliance including tariff classification (HTS), country-of-origin rules, Free Trade Agreement documentation, antidumping/countervailing duties, and forced labor prohibitions (e.g., UFLPA). Violations carry civil and criminal penalties.
requirement: Importers must ensure accurate documentation, classification, and adherence to regulatory import conditions to avoid enforcement actions.

name: GDPR Chapter V
description: Regulates personal data transfers outside the EEA, requiring adequate protection through mechanisms like adequacy decisions, Standard Contractual Clauses (SCCs), or specific derogations. Schrems II decision introduced transfer impact assessments and supplemental safeguards.
requirement: Personal data can only be transferred out of the EEA if adequate safeguards are in place or exceptions apply, with mandatory transfer impact assessments.

name: EU Standard Contractual Clauses (2021 SCCs)
description: Legal mechanism approved by the European Commission enabling cross-border transfers of personal data. Modular clauses cover different transfer scenarios and embed Schrems II requirements including law assessments and technical/organizational safeguards.
requirement: Entities must adopt updated SCCs with impact assessments and security measures for cross-border data transfers.

name: EU-US Data Privacy Framework
description: New transatlantic arrangement replacing the Privacy Shield. Allows certified US companies to receive EU personal data under enhanced privacy safeguards and redress mechanisms. Received EU adequacy decision in July 2023.
requirement: US organizations must self-certify under the framework and comply with oversight and redress rules.

name: Chinese PIPL Cross-Border Provisions
description: Requires personal information exports to pass a CAC security assessment, certification, or standard contracts. Critical data and large-scale processors are subject to data localization. Transfers must be justified and transparent to data subjects.
requirement: Entities transferring data abroad must pass government review, sign contracts, and inform users. Localization applies to CIIOs and large processors.

name: Russian Data Localization Law (Federal Law No. 242-FZ)
description: Mandates that personal data of Russian citizens be stored in databases located in Russia. Enforced by Roskomnadzor, with violations leading to fines or access restrictions to services.
requirement: Operators collecting data from Russian citizens must store it on Russian servers and maintain a primary domestic database.

name: Indian Cross-Border Requirements (RBI and DPDP Act 2023)
type: Sectoral and General Data Transfer Regulation
description: RBI mandates local storage of payment system data. The 2023 DPDP Act allows cross-border transfers to notified countries while granting the government the power to restrict transfers to others.
requirement: Payment data must remain in India; other personal data may be transferred to approved countries per new DPDP rules.

name: Vietnam Cybersecurity Law
description: Requires certain domestic and foreign service providers to store personal and service data of Vietnamese users in Vietnam. Applies to telecom, internet, e-commerce, and cloud service providers.
requirement: Applicable companies must store and retain user data in Vietnam and may face suspension or license loss for violations.

name: Regional Data Localization Requirements (Asia-Pacific, Brazil, Saudi Arabia)
description: Varied national approaches: Indonesia requires domestic data centers; South Korea restricts mapping/finance data; Japan allows transfers with safeguards; Brazil’s LGPD mimics GDPR; Saudi Arabia regulates cross-border cloud storage.
jurisdiction: Indonesia, South Korea, Japan, Brazil, Saudi Arabia
requirement: Country-specific laws mandate localized data storage, transfer restrictions, or contractual safeguards based on sector and type of data.

name: HIPAA and HITECH Act
description: HIPAA establishes privacy, security, and breach notification rules for protected health information (PHI). The HITECH Act expanded these rules to business associates and increased penalties.
requirement: Healthcare providers and associates must safeguard PHI with administrative, physical, and technical controls. Violations can result in penalties up to $1.5 million per category.

name: 21 CFR Part 11
description: FDA regulation governing electronic records and signatures for compliance in regulated environments. Requires validation, secure audit trails, and restricted access.
requirement: Entities using electronic records for FDA-regulated processes must ensure integrity and security of data and e-signatures.

name: EU Health Data Protections (GDPR Art. 9, EHDS, MDR, IVDR)
description: Health data is classified as 'special category' under GDPR, requiring explicit consent or legal basis. EHDS aims to enable secure health data sharing. MDR/IVDR impose cybersecurity and safety requirements on medical devices.
requirement: Processing of health data requires strong safeguards and legal justification. Medical devices must meet cybersecurity criteria.

name: Financial Regulations (SOX, Basel III, MiFID II, PSD2, PCI-DSS, AML/KYC)
description: Regulations including SOX (internal controls), Basel III (capital adequacy), MiFID II (EU investment), PSD2 (payment services), PCI-DSS (cardholder data security), and AML/KYC requirements globally.
requirement: Organizations must ensure secure financial reporting, data protection in transactions, and robust customer due diligence.
effective_date: Varies: SOX 2002, MiFID II 2018, PSD2 2018, PCI-DSS ongoing

name: FERPA, COPPA, State & International Student Privacy Laws
description: FERPA protects student education records in US institutions. COPPA regulates online data collection from children under 13. State laws and international frameworks like UK’s Age Appropriate Design Code add child-specific privacy protections.
requirement: Institutions and service providers must obtain parental consent and prevent misuse of student data. Privacy-by-design principles apply to child-oriented services.

name: FedRAMP, NIST SP 800-171, CMMC, FAR/DFARS, International Equivalents
description: FedRAMP standardizes cloud security for US agencies. NIST SP 800-171 and CMMC set requirements for handling controlled unclassified info. FAR/DFARS clauses mandate incident response and reporting. UK and NATO equivalents enforce similar controls.
requirement: Federal contractors and agencies must implement cybersecurity controls, report incidents, and meet certification thresholds.

name: NERC CIP, EPA Regulations, ESG & Energy Sector Standards
description: NERC CIP mandates cyber and operational controls for electric grid operators. EPA enforces risk management and reporting. ESG frameworks include SASB, TCFD, EU Taxonomy, CDP reporting, TSA pipeline directives, and IEC 62443 industrial cybersecurity standards.
requirement: Operators must implement physical/cybersecurity safeguards, environmental risk plans, and disclose climate impacts under ESG metrics.
effective_date: NERC CIP 2008, EPA RMP ongoing, ESG standards ongoing

name: ISO/IEC 27001
description: International standard specifying requirements for establishing, implementing, maintaining, and continually improving an ISMS. Features 114 controls in 14 domains with a risk-based approach and mandatory certification audits.
requirement: Organizations must develop a risk-based ISMS and undergo certification by accredited bodies with surveillance audits and recertification every three years.

name: SOC 2
description: AICPA framework for assessing controls related to security, availability, processing integrity, confidentiality, and privacy. Includes Type 1 (point in time) and Type 2 (operational over time) reports.
requirement: Organizations undergo independent attestation by CPA firms, choosing relevant trust categories for evaluation.

name: NIST Cybersecurity Framework (CSF)
description: Voluntary framework organizing cybersecurity efforts into Identify, Protect, Detect, Respond, and Recover functions. Includes implementation tiers and control mappings to other standards.
requirement: Organizations adopt the CSF to manage cyber risks using a tailored profile and maturity model. CSF 2.0 expands governance and supply chain coverage.

name: CIS Controls
description: Prescriptive set of 18 prioritized security controls grouped into three implementation tiers based on organizational size and maturity. Focuses on core security hygiene and is backed by platform-specific guidance and benchmarks.
requirement: Organizations implement foundational controls starting with asset inventory and vulnerability management, progressing to more advanced practices.

name: OWASP Top 10
description: List of the ten most critical web application security risks based on data analysis and expert input. Serves as a baseline for secure development and testing practices.
requirement: Developers and security teams use the Top 10 to prevent and detect common application vulnerabilities such as broken access control and injection.

name: CSA STAR / CAIQ
description: Cloud Security Alliance's STAR program includes a public registry and tiered assurance levels. CAIQ questionnaire and Cloud Controls Matrix support transparency and due diligence in cloud provider evaluations.
requirement: Cloud service providers submit CAIQ responses or undergo third-party certification to demonstrate alignment with CSA controls.

name: Shared Assessments SIG
description: Standardized Information Gathering questionnaire with 1,000+ questions covering key risk domains including data security and resilience. Includes SIG Core and SIG Lite versions.
requirement: Organizations use SIG to evaluate vendor security and compliance posture across a standardized framework.

name: PCI-DSS
type: Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard
description: Security standard for organizations that store, process, or transmit cardholder data. Includes 12 core requirements and a mix of self-assessment and audit requirements based on transaction volume.
requirement: Organizations must meet the standard’s requirements to handle payment card data and avoid penalties or loss of processing privileges.

name: EU AI Act
description: First comprehensive legal framework for AI using a risk-based approach to categorize AI systems (unacceptable, high, limited, minimal risk), with requirements for transparency, human oversight, and documentation.
requirement: Applies to all AI systems used or placing outputs on the market in the EU, with obligations varying by risk category.

name: NIST AI Risk Management Framework
description: Voluntary framework to help organizations manage risks associated with AI across its lifecycle with a focus on trustworthiness, accountability, and human-centric values.
requirement: Organizations can use it to assess and improve AI trustworthiness through structured risk management practices.

name: Singapore Model AI Governance Framework
description: Framework offering practical guidance on internal governance, AI decision-making models, and operational management for responsible AI deployment.
requirement: Organizations are encouraged to adopt practices for fairness, explainability, and robustness in AI systems.

name: IEEE P7000 Series
description: Series of IEEE standards addressing ethics in AI systems including data privacy, algorithmic bias, children's data, and system transparency.
requirement: Designed for integration into AI development lifecycles to promote responsible design and deployment practices.
effective_date: Series under rolling release (varies by standard)

name: ISO/IEC 42001
description: International standard providing requirements for establishing and maintaining an AI management system with emphasis on ethics, risk, and lifecycle governance.
requirement: Organizations must define policies, controls, and oversight for ethical AI development and operation.

name: OECD AI Principles
description: Principles promoting trustworthy AI development that respects human rights, promotes transparency, accountability, and robustness.
requirement: Countries and organizations use them as a benchmark for creating or aligning AI policies and national strategies.

name: China’s Algorithmic Recommendation Regulations
description: Rules requiring transparency in algorithmic content selection, opt-out options, and protection against discrimination for users interacting with recommendation systems.
requirement: Platform providers must allow user control, disclose algorithm functionality, and prevent misuse or discrimination.

name: Canada’s Artificial Intelligence and Data Act (AIDA)
description: Proposed legislation establishing requirements for high-impact AI systems, including risk assessments, outcome monitoring, and transparency obligations.
requirement: High-impact AI systems must meet compliance obligations related to safety, fairness, and auditability.

name: Digital Services Act / Digital Markets Act
description: The DSA establishes rules for online platforms to ensure content moderation, transparency, and user protection, while the DMA regulates large digital gatekeepers to ensure fair competition.
requirement: Online platforms and large tech companies must comply with obligations around moderation, data access, self-assessments, and fair digital practices.

name: Digital Operational Resilience Act (DORA)
description: Establishes uniform digital resilience requirements for financial institutions including ICT risk management, incident reporting, and resilience testing.
requirement: Financial entities must adopt robust ICT risk frameworks, monitor third-party risks, and regularly test operational resilience.

name: NIS2 Directive
description: Enhances cybersecurity requirements and expands the scope to more sectors and entities with risk management and incident reporting obligations.
requirement: Essential and important entities must implement security measures, report incidents, and ensure business continuity planning.

name: ePrivacy Regulation (proposed)
description: Proposed regulation to enhance privacy in electronic communications, covering cookies, metadata, and communication confidentiality. Complements GDPR.
requirement: Would impose stricter rules for cookies, tracking technologies, and metadata handling in electronic communications.

name: UK Online Safety Bill
description: UK regulation imposing duties on online platforms to assess and mitigate online harms, including illegal and harmful content, particularly for children.
requirement: Platforms must conduct risk assessments, enforce content moderation systems, and provide safety tools for users.

name: Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive (CSRD)
description: Enhanced EU framework requiring detailed sustainability disclosures from large companies and listed SMEs, following European Sustainability Reporting Standards (ESRS) and incorporating double materiality assessments.
requirement: Companies must report on environmental, social, and governance matters, integrating both financial and impact materiality perspectives.

name: Modern Slavery Acts (UK & Australia)
description: Laws requiring businesses to publish annual statements on actions taken to prevent modern slavery in their operations and supply chains. Aimed at improving accountability and ethical sourcing.
requirement: Companies above a certain size must publish modern slavery statements annually addressing due diligence and risk mitigation.

name: Supply Chain Due Diligence Laws (Germany & France)
type: Human Rights and Environmental Due Diligence
description: German Supply Chain Act and French Duty of Vigilance Law require companies to identify, prevent, and mitigate human rights and environmental risks throughout their global supply chains.
requirement: Large companies must establish due diligence or vigilance frameworks and publish reports on risk management practices.

name: Climate-related Financial Disclosures (TCFD-Aligned)
description: Disclosure standards based on TCFD recommendations requiring companies to report on governance, strategy, risk management, and metrics related to climate change. Becoming mandatory in several countries.
jurisdiction: United Kingdom, New Zealand, Singapore, Switzerland
requirement: Covered entities must assess and disclose their climate-related risks and opportunities in alignment with TCFD guidance.
